  46018: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":29:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"46018\";s:3:\"url\";s:119:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/europe-must-take-action-to-protect-lgbt-people-in-the-workplace-46018\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-17 13:58:15\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-17 13:41:10\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-17 13:58:17\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:106:\"Read the full analysis of working life experiences of LGBT people and initiatives to tackle discrimination\";s:3:\"url\";s:21:\"http://bit.ly/LGBTexp\";}}s:6:\"header\";s:63:\"Europe must take action to protect LGBT people in the workplace\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:9801:\"<p><em>This article, originally posted on&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/LGBTAction\" target=\"_blank\">Social Europe Journal</a>,&nbsp;is based on a comprehensive&nbsp;overview of surveys on the working life experiences of LGBT people in the EU. Read it in full&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/LGBTexp\" target=\"_blank\">here</a></em><em>.&nbsp;</em></p><p>17 May is <a href=\"http://dayagainsthomophobia.org/\" target=\"_blank\">International day against homophobia, transphobia and biphobia</a>. Lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) people face distinct disadvantages in the labour market ranging from discrimination in recruitment, wages or promotions to harassment and bullying in the workplace. Such problems are present across the entire EU and on average, 19% of LGBT employees feels discriminated at work.</p><p>Conditions in some countries are worse than in others. Initiatives aimed at addressing prejudice tend to be implemented in countries that are already more tolerant towards LGBT. By contrast, governments and the social partners are largely inactive in countries where there is more acute prejudice; if any action is taken, it tends to come from NGOs. Reaching consensus at EU has proven to be problematic, as shown by the recent failure to find agreement on a list of actions to promote LGBTI equality at a March meeting of the council of employment and social affairs ministers (EPSCO).</p><h2>Legally protected but discriminated against</h2><p>In the EU, <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=celex%3A32000L0078\" target=\"_blank\">the Employment Equality Directive (2000/78/EC)</a> and <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32006L0054\" target=\"_blank\">Employment and Social Security Directive (2006/54/EC)</a> forbid discrimination in employment based on – among other grounds – sexual orientation and sexual identity. Despite the legal protection that LGBT people enjoy, a new<a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/observatories/eurwork/articles/working-conditions-labour-market-law-and-regulation/working-life-experiences-of-lgbt-people-and-initiatives-to-tackle-discrimination\">Eurofound paper</a> presents overwhelming evidence that they face discrimination in recruitment and employment.</p><p>The <a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/index_en.htm\" target=\"_blank\">Eurobarometer survey</a> from 2015 shows that in northern and western Europe people seem to be more comfortable with having LGBT work colleagues. However, LGBT colleagues experience more issues in eastern and southern EU Member States. In all countries, the unease felt by having a transgender colleague is even stronger than in the case of gay men, lesbians or bisexuals.</p><p>These differences in public attitudes are reflected in reported incidents of discrimination. The Fundamental Rights Agency’s (FRA) <a href=\"http://fra.europa.eu/en/survey/2012/eu-lgbt-survey\" target=\"_blank\">EU LGBT survey</a> 2012 has revealed that one in five (19%) LGBT employees in the EU felt discriminated at work in the 12 months preceding the survey. Generally, Baltic and Balkan Member States had the highest proportions of LGBT employees who felt discriminated at work. A body of national surveys and academic research also indicates that LGBT employees face distinct disadvantages at the workplace compared to their heterosexual colleagues.</p><p><strong>Figure 1: Proportion of LGBT employees who felt discriminated at work (in 12 months preceding the survey) and who always hide or disguise being LGBT at work (in 5 years preceding the survey) per country (EU28, 2012)</strong></p><p><img src=\"https://www.socialeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/fric_graph.png\" alt=\"fric_graph\" width=\"758\" height=\"723\" style=\"display: block; margin: 0px auto 24px;\"></p><p><em>Source: </em> <a href=\"http://fra.europa.eu/en/publications-and-resources/data-and-maps/survey-data-explorer-lgbt-survey-2012\" target=\"_blank\">FRA LGBT Survey 2012 data explorer</a></p><h2></h2><h2>Secret at work</h2><p>Many LGBT employees are forced to hide their sexual orientation at work due to fear of discrimination and harassment. The extent of discrimination reported by LGBT respondents is particularly alarming since almost a third (29%) always hide their sexual identity and orientation at work. The number of respondents who felt able to disclose their sexual orientation or identity at work was lowest in Baltic and Balkan EU Member States. Hiding one’s sexual orientation <a href=\"http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1086/661653\" target=\"_blank\">is often stressful</a> and may have a negative impact on the individual’s productivity, self-esteem, depth of friendships, and ability to work as part of a team.</p><p>The social stigma attached to being LGBT can be so acute as to even discourage victims of discrimination or harassment from coming forward. For this reason, traditional measures of discrimination that are applied to that based on sexual orientation are likely to under-report the severity of the issue. This lack of reliable information forms a barrier in addressing the discrimination of LGBT people on the labour market.</p><h2></h2><h2>Actions of social partners and governments</h2><p>In order to address the position of LGBT people in society and in the labour market, the European Commission published in December 2015 a <a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/justice/discrimination/files/lgbti_actionlist_en.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">list of specific targeted actions aimed at combating LGBTI discrimination in the EU in 2016–2019</a>. In February 2016, the <a href=\"http://europa.eu/whoiswho/public/index.cfm?fuseaction=idea.hierarchy&amp;nodeid=3760\" target=\"_blank\">Permanent Representatives Committee</a> of the Council of the EU reached an <a href=\"http://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-6255-2016-INIT/en/pdf\">agreement</a> on a list of actions to promote LGBTI equality. However, in March 2016, the EPSCO Council was unable to reach majority support for the text. Nearly all Member States supported the list of actions, however <a href=\"http://www.lgbt-ep.eu/press-releases/meps-welcome-member-states-support-to-commissions-actions-on-lgbti-equality-deplore-opposition-of-hungary/\" target=\"_blank\">Hungary prevented</a> the conclusion of a final agreement in the Council . <a href=\"http://www.euinside.eu/en/news/hungary-again-tripped-the-eu-with-the-support-of-poland-lgbti\">According to the Hungarian representative</a>, LGBTI “is a complex, politically highly sensitive issue for many member states, it touches upon questions belonging to the exclusive competence of the member states, like family law, and it has an effect on the member states’ constitutional rules, principles and values”.</p><p><a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/justice/discrimination/files/sen_synthesisreport2010parti_en.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">The report of The Network of Socio-Economic Experts in the Non-Discrimination Field</a> from 2010 concludes that the policies aimed at improving access to work for LGBT people are inadequate throughout Europe. The amount of attention social partners and governments pay to LGBT issues in the labour market varies between Member States.</p><p>In northern and western Europe, in countries such as <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/observatories/eurwork/articles/working-conditions-labour-market-quality-of-life/denmark-greater-acceptance-of-lgbt-colleagues-in-female-dominated-workplaceshttp:/www.eurofound.europa.eu/observatories/eurwork/articles/working-conditions-labour-market-quality-of-life/denmark-greater-acceptance-of-lgbt-colleagues-in-female-dominated-workplaces\" target=\"_blank\">Denmark</a>, Ireland, Netherlands and Sweden, there is a pro-active and comprehensive approach to preventing and combating discrimination of LGBT people in the labour market. In some other countries, such as Belgium, Germany, France and Italy the promotion of rights of LGBT workers is less common, or involves only specific actors. The situation is different in many new Member States. The governments and social partners in Cyprus, Czechia, Hungary, Latvia, Romania or Slovakia have not taken any significant actions that would address the situation of LGBT employees. In these countries, LGBT people do not exert sufficient influence in social partners organisations so advocacy aimed at promoting LGBT rights in the labour market is therefore mostly driven by NGOs.</p><p>A variety of initiatives can be identified around Europe aimed at combatting discrimination against LGBT people – action plans or public commitments, awareness campaigns, training activities, workshops, networking activities for employers or LGBT employees, sharing of good practices or help for victims of discrimination. In Germany, Netherlands and Spain, guidelines and checklists were developed advising how to to address LGBT equality issues in collective agreements.</p><h2></h2><h2>Action is lacking where it is needed the most</h2><p>One significant issue is that social partners’ and governments’ initiatives are lacking especially in countries where public attitudes towards LGBT people are relatively more regressive. This is not simply due to a <a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/justice/discrimination/files/sen_synthesisreport2010parti_en.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">lack of political</a> will, but also to lack of knowledge about the labour market situation of LGBT people and their high level of invisibility. Such a situation is worrying, because the promotion of LGBT rights in the workplace happens least in countries where it is needed the most. This in turn contributes to maintaining social stigma.</p><p><em>by&nbsp;</em><a href=\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/contact_people/karel-fric-research-officer-44447\" target=\"_blank\">Karel Fric</a></p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/pdiywwubl1lftifj2lqd.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/pdiywwubl1lftifj2lqd.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/pdiywwubl1lftifj2lqd.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/pdiywwubl1lftifj2lqd.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/pdiywwubl1lftifj2lqd.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/pdiywwubl1lftifj2lqd.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:2:{i:0;s:18:\"working   45896: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":29:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"45896\";s:3:\"url\";s:191:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/strong-partnerships-between-governments-and-social-partners-are-essential-to-ensure-freedom-from-trafficking-and-exploitation-in-europe-45896\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-16 09:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-12 09:32:47\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-16 09:00:10\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";a:2:{i:0;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:97:\"Listen to Andrea Fromm speak about the new report on preventing the trafficking of labour ​here\";s:3:\"url\";s:30:\"http://bit.ly/TraffickingAudio\";}i:1;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:132:\"Download the report 'Regulation of labour market intermediaries and the role of social partners in preventing trafficking of labour'\";s:3:\"url\";s:33:\"http://bit.ly/Prevent-Trafficking\";}}}s:6:\"header\";s:123:\"Strong partnerships between governments and social partners are essential to prevent trafficking and exploitation in Europe\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:3434:\"<p><em>[Listen to Eurofound Research Officer Andrea Fromm introduce the new report on preventing the trafficking of labour&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/TraffickingAudio\" target=\"_blank\">here</a>.]</em></p><p><em>&nbsp;</em></p><p><em><strong>Workers are mobile and can move freely within the EU single market across borders. In order to protect these workers from being exploited and enables businesses to engage in fair competition, the </strong></em><strong><em>EU has strong legislation in place<em>. But does that mean that trafficking does not exist within the EU’s borders?</em></em></strong></p><p>The new Eurofound report&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/Prevent-Trafficking\">Regulation of labour market intermediaries and the role of social partners in preventing trafficking of labour</a> shows that trafficking for labour exploitation does exist in Europe and that in some case labour market intermediaries are involved. According to <a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/3888793/6648090/KS-TC-14-008-EN-1.pdf/b0315d39-e7bd-4da5-8285-854f37bb8801\">Eurostat</a>, 19% of all identified and presumed victims were trafficked for the purpose of labour exploitation. In some cases labour market intermediaries recruit or transfer workers unlawfully, they deceive workers about their future job, and workers end up working under exploitative conditions.</p><p>The&nbsp;<a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2011:101:0001:0011:EN:PDF\">Anti-Trafficking Directive</a> underlines that trafficking is a serious crime and a gross violation of fundamental rights. Germany is the only country which has failed to transpose the Directive. In this context the report finds that monitoring labour market intermediaries, including temporary work agencies, needs to be improved. Tripartite partnerships also need to be strengthened; this is crucial to achieve effective enforcement and prosecution.</p><p>The regulation of labour market intermediaries takes a variety of forms in the EU. Registration or licensing schemes are common to monitor compliance with minimum standards, yet coverage of labour market intermediaries is inadequate. As a result, sanctioning labour market intermediaries that are engaged in trafficking is challenging at best.</p><p>Improved cooperation with social partners is also needed. Some good examples exist already: the involvement of social partners in international and European initiatives, awareness-raising campaigns, in establishing complaint mechanisms, developing codes of conduct, and engaging in cross-border cooperation.</p><p>To date, a tripartite partnership to tackle trafficking has only been created by the Czech Republic. Targeted policy interventions were developed, cross-border cooperation initiated, the number of inspections was increased, training was broadened, and the compilation of a company blacklist agreed.</p><p>Tackling trafficking for labour exploitation is not only an important way to facilitate free and safe mobility of workers and the effective functioning of EU labour markets; it is also an essential tool to boost fair competition. Above all, the EU has a commitment to protect people’s basic human rights. Better monitoring and a dedicated partnership between governments and social partners is essential; essential for ensuring not only freedom from being trafficked and exploited, but also freedom to live and work in dignity.</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/qwrpyygrwa117mrbok78.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/qwrpyygrwa117mrbok78.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/qwrpyygrwa117mrbok78.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/qwrpyygrwa117mrbok78.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/qwrpyygrwa117mrbok78.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/qwrpyygrwa117mrbok78.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:3:{i:0;s:18:\"law   45734: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":29:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"it\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"45734\";s:3:\"url\";s:136:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/misure-a-sostegno-delle-start-up-giovanili-dall-implementazione-alla-valutazione-45734\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-05 14:40:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-05 10:54:05\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-05 14:40:04\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";a:3:{i:0;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:85:\"​Cliccare qui per ascoltare la ricercatrice Sara Riso introdurre il nuovo rapporto \";s:3:\"url\";s:28:\"http://bit.ly/GiovaniStartup\";}i:1;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:57:\"Cliccare qui per scaricare l'intero rapporto (in inglese)\";s:3:\"url\";s:26:\"http://bit.ly/StartupYouth\";}i:2;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:63:\"Cliccare qui per scaricare il sommario del rapporto in italiano\";s:3:\"url\";s:29:\"http://bit.ly/SostegnoStartup\";}}}s:6:\"header\";s:83:\"Misure a sostegno delle start-up giovanili: dall’implementazione alla valutazione\";s:7:\"summary\";s:2:\"\n\n\";s:4:\"body\";s:3557:\"<p><em><a href=\"http://bit.ly/GiovaniStartup\" target=\"_blank\">Cliccare qui</a> per ascoltare&nbsp;la ricercatrice Sara Riso introdurre il nuovo rapporto&nbsp;</em></p><p><em><br></em></p><p><strong>Il nuovo rapporto di Eurofound ‘<a href=\"http://bit.ly/StartupYouth\" target=\"_blank\">misure a sostegno delle start-up giovanili: dall’implementazione alla valutazione</a></strong><strong>’ offre una mappatura della varietà delle misure agevolative a favore delle start-up giovanili e rivisita in modo critico i risultati che emergono da valutazioni di tali interventi volte a stabilire la loro efficacia e impatto.</strong></p><p>Un primo punto che emerge da questo rapporto è che l’Unione Europea non manca  di misure a sostegno delle start-up giovanili. Molte delle iniziative in questo ambito fanno parte della Garanzia Giovani, e un numero considerevole sono misure di attivazione lavorativa rivolte ai disoccupati, ivi inclusi i giovani alla ricerca di una prima occupazione.  Il tipo di sostegno offerto spazia dall’accesso ai finanziamenti e strumenti di credito vari al cosiddetto supporto ‘soft’ che include servizi di orientamento e assistenza personalizzata, attività di mentoring, tirocini e percorsi di formazione mirata, e quanto altro necessario per sostenere gli aspiranti e neo giovani imprenditori.  </p><p>Sebbene la Garanzia Giovani abbia unificato sotto un’unica strategia interventi disparati a sostegno dell’imprenditorialità giovanile per la promozione dell’occupazione dei giovani, resta ancora tanto da fare per arrivare a un migliore coordinamento e ad una maggiore complementarietà degli interventi in questione.  Il punto dolente sta proprio nella frammentazione delle iniziative e delle politiche. La maggior parte delle misure a sostegno delle start-up giovanili sono interventi isolati, relativamente di piccola entità e con risorse limitate. Questo non aiuta in termini di impatto.  </p><p>Nonostante l’imprenditorialità giovanile susciti un grande e crescente interesse da parte dei politici, poche azioni vengono intraprese per verificare l’efficacia degli strumenti a disposizione.  </p><p>Si preferiscono forme di valutazione meno scientifiche, che poggiano su dati che si riferiscono al numero dei beneficiari o opinioni sulla qualità dell’assistenza ricevuta.  Risultati più positivi emergono proprio da questo tipo di valutazioni piuttosto che da valutazioni che hanno adottato approcci più scientifici.  </p><p>Sono poche le valutazioni di misure a sostegno delle start-up giovanili che poggiano su metodi più rigorosi e spesso i risultati indicano un impatto limitato o completamente assente.  Nel contesto dell’implementazione della Garanzia Giovani e un possibile aumento della spesa pubblica  per l’attuazione di misure rivolte al sostegno dell’imprenditorialità’ giovanile, c’è un assoluto, pressante bisogno di concepire delle politiche fondate sui fatti concreti e prove di efficacia. I risultati che emergono da valutazioni rigorose e di più ampio respiro devono stabilire una dinamica circolare e informare  una progettazione oculata delle politiche per, a sua volta, rendere gli interventi più efficaci. Questo significa che la valutazione non è alla fine del percorso, ma deve essere parte integrante della progettazione politica e del concepimento degli interventi a sostegno dell’imprenditorialità giovanile. E’ possibile in tal modo avviare interventi più efficaci senza paura e riserva alcuna di mettere da parte ciò che non funziona.&nbsp;</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/umjnphoanh6tyq706ior.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/umjnphoanh6tyq706ior.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/umjnphoanh6tyq706ior.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/umjnphoanh6tyq706ior.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/umjnphoanh6tyq706ior.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/umjnphoanh6tyq706ior.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:3:{i:0;s:8:\"business\";i:1;s:13:\"labour market\";i:2;s:15:\"social policies\";}}s:8:\"subjects\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:7:\"subject\";a:6:{i:0;s:17:\"Employment issues\";i:1;s:17:\"Social conditions\";i:2;s:7:\"Reports\";i:3;s:21:\"European Union issues\";i:4;s:15:\"Children, Youth\";i:5;s:19:\"Working Environment\";}}s:14:\"contact_people\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:14:\"contact_person\";a:2:{i:0;O:8:\"stdClass\":28:{s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"39071\";s:3:\"url\";s:59:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/contact_people/39071\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2013-11-25   45656: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":29:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"45656\";s:3:\"url\";s:135:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/tackling-trafficking-for-labour-exploitation-in-europe-new-way-forward-together-45656\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-03 12:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-03 11:06:45\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-03 12:00:11\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";a:3:{i:0;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:130:\"Download the report Regulation of labour market intermediaries and the role of social partners in preventing trafficking of labour\";s:3:\"url\";s:33:\"http://bit.ly/Prevent-Trafficking\";}i:1;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:94:\"Image © European Union, 2015 - Source EC - Audiovisual Service - Photo by Tzortzinis Angelos \";s:3:\"url\";s:0:\"\";}i:2;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:91:\"Image © European Union, 2015 - Source EC Audiovisual Service, Photo by Tzortzinis Angelos \";s:3:\"url\";s:31:\"http://ec.europa.eu/avservices/\";}}}s:6:\"header\";s:80:\"Tackling Trafficking For Labour Exploitation In Europe: New Way Forward Together\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:6767:\"<p><em>This article by Andrea Fromm&nbsp;was originally posted on&nbsp;</em><a href=\"https://www.socialeurope.eu/\" target=\"_blank\">Social Europe Journal</a><em>, to view it please click&nbsp;</em><a href=\"http://bit.ly/TraffickingSEJ\" target=\"_blank\">here</a><em>.&nbsp;</em></p><p><em><br></em></p><p>The European Union (EU) has strong legislation in place that protects workers from being exploited and also enables businesses to engage in fair competition. Workers are mobile and can move freely within the EU single market across borders – without being dependent upon traffickers. Yet, the <a href=\"https://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/report/2016/labour-market-industrial-relations/regulation-of-labour-market-intermediaries-and-the-role-of-social-partners-in-preventing-trafficking\" target=\"_blank\">latest Eurofound report</a> shows that trafficking for labour exploitation in Europe does exist. <a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/3888793/6648090/KS-TC-14-008-EN-1.pdf/b0315d39-e7bd-4da5-8285-854f37bb8801\" target=\"_blank\">Eurostat</a>’s latest figures show that 19% of all identified and presumed victims were trafficked for the purpose of labour exploitation, sexual exploitation being excluded. Our report urges stronger implementation of regulation and joint action by social partners to crack down on trafficking for labour exploitation.</p><p>Labour market intermediaries (LMIs) such as temporary work agencies help to facilitate the mobility of workers through matching workers with companies’ needs. According to the <a href=\"http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?query=BOOKMARK_DS-120959_QID_41A5C4B9_UID_-3F171EB0&amp;layout=TIME,C,X,0;GEO,L,Y,0;NACE_R2,L,Z,0;INDIC_SB,L,Z,1;SIZE_EMP,L,Z,2;INDICATORS,C,Z,3;&amp;zSelection=DS-120959INDICATORS,OBS_FLAG;DS-120959NACE_R2,H;DS-120959SIZE_EMP,TOTAL;DS-120959INDIC_SB,V11110;&amp;rankName1=SIZE-EMP_1_2_-1_2&amp;rankName2=INDICATORS_1_2_-1_2&amp;rankName3=INDIC-SB_1_2_-1_2&amp;rankName4=NACE-R2_1_2_-1_2&amp;rankName5=TIME_1_0_0_0&amp;rankName6=GEO_1_2_0_1&amp;sortC=ASC_-1_FIRST&amp;rStp=&amp;cStp=&amp;rDCh=&amp;cDCh=&amp;rDM=true&amp;cDM=true&amp;footnes=false&amp;empty=false&amp;wai=false&amp;time_mode=FIXED&amp;time_most_recent=false&amp;lang=EN&amp;cfo=%23%23%23%2C%23%23%23.%23%23%23\" target=\"_blank\">Structural Business Statistics</a> more than 33,000 temporary work agencies operate in Europe aiding job matching and mobility within and across borders. So clearly there should not be any business for individuals or companies engaging in illegal trafficking within or across EU Member States. But, unfortunately, there is.</p><p>In some cases, LMIs use their role to recruit or transfer workers unlawfully. They deceive workers about the nature of the job, the employer, the location or other conditions related to the work, and these workers end up working under exploitative conditions.</p><p>In 2011 the EU adopted the <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2011:101:0001:0011:EN:PDF\" target=\"_blank\">Anti-Trafficking Directive</a>. The directive emphasises that trafficking is a serious crime and a gross violation of fundamental rights. <a href=\"https://ec.europa.eu/anti-trafficking/sites/antitrafficking/files/eu_strategy_towards_the_eradication_of_trafficking_in_human_beings_2012-2016_1.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">The EU Strategy towards the Eradication of Trafficking in Human Beings 2012–2016</a> complements the legal rules with targeted actions – and recruitment by LMIs is indeed one area of concern.</p><p>It is puzzling that, although trafficking for labour exploitation has been criminalised at EU level, the recent numbers, according to <a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/3888793/6648090/KS-TC-14-008-EN-1.pdf/b0315d39-e7bd-4da5-8285-854f37bb8801\" target=\"_blank\">Eurostat</a>, of prosecuted traffickers are stagnant. The Eurofound report provides one possible answer. It finds that monitoring LMIs needs to be strengthened to achieve greater enforcement, sanctioning and prosecution. The report also shows that building tripartite partnerships, including across borders, is necessary to&nbsp;implement coherent activities. One way of preventing LMIs from engaging in trafficking is by monitoring their compliance with national rules and regulations.</p><p>Regulating the operation of LMIs takes a variety of forms in the 28 EU Member States and Norway (which also participated in the study). Registration or licensing schemes are common across Europe to monitor who is operating an LMI and to ensure compliance with minimum standards in running the business. Yet coverage of registered, licensed or certified LMIs is inadequate. This contributes to the challenge of&nbsp;sanctioning illegally operating LMIs that are engaged at the entry point of trafficking.</p><p>Greater commitment of and cooperation with social partners is also needed. Member States and public authorities in particular can benefit from social partners’ expertise on working and business conditions and their networks to fight trafficking. Involvement of the social partners in international and European initiatives, awareness-raising campaigns, establishing complaint mechanisms, developing codes of conduct, distributing educational material and engaging in cross-border cooperation with other trade unions or employer organisations are underway.</p><p>Yet a tripartite partnership to tackle trafficking has been created in only one country of the EU – the&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/observatories/eurwork/comparative-information/national-contributions/czech-republic/czech-republic-regulation-of-labour-market-intermediaries-and-role-of-the-social-partners-in\" target=\"_blank\">Czech Republic</a>. Targeted policy interventions were developed, cross-border cooperation initiated, a tripartite working group established. In addition the number of inspections was increased, training was broadened to relevant groups, a cooperation agreement by the social partners signed and the compilation of a company blacklist agreed.</p><p>Tackling trafficking for labour exploitation is not only an important way to facilitate free and safe mobility of workers and the effective functioning of EU labour markets. It is also an essential tool to boost fair competition. Above all, however, it is the commitment of the EU as enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights to protect people’s basic human rights against violations in order to create an area of freedom, security and justice.</p><p>A better and dedicated partnership between governments and social partners is needed to ensure not only freedom <em>from</em> being trafficked and exploited but also freedom <em>to</em> live and work in dignity.</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/njyoeoj8sbvbmcsv058s.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/njyoeoj8sbvbmcsv058s.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/njyoeoj8sbvbmcsv058s.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/njyoeoj8sbvbmcsv058s.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/njyoeoj8sbvbmcsv058s.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/njyoeoj8sbvbmcsv058s.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:3:{i:0;s:18:\"working   45231: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":29:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"45231\";s:3:\"url\";s:136:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/start-up-support-schemes-need-to-be-evaluated-on-their-outcomes-for-young-people-45231\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-26 11:10:35\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-19 16:11:51\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-26 implementation to evaluation\";s:3:\"url\";s:26:\"http://bit.ly/StartupYouth\";}i:2;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:92:\"Read Sara Riso's Blog piece on Avoiding The Quick Fix Approach To Solving Youth Unemployment\";s:3:\"url\";s:24:\"http://bit.ly/SEJStartUp\";}}}s:6:\"header\";s:80:\"Start-up support schemes need to be evaluated on their outcomes for young people\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:2606:\"<p><i style=\"background-color: initial;\">**&nbsp;Listen to Eurofound Research Officer Sara Riso introduce the Start-up support for young people publication&nbsp;</i><a href=\"http://bit.ly/AudioStartUp\" target=\"_blank\">here</a>.<i style=\"background-color: initial;\">**</i></p><p><strong><br></strong></p><p><strong></strong><strong>The new Eurofound report ‘</strong><a href=\"http://bit.ly/StartupYouth\" target=\"_blank\">Start-up support for young people: From implementation to evaluation</a><strong>’ maps the variety of publicly supported interventions on youth entrepreneurship and reviews a range of policy evaluations assessing their impact and effectiveness.</strong></p><p>What becomes apparent from the report is that there is no shortage of start-up support measures for young people in the EU. Many of these measures, including general activation measures for the unemployed, are currently part of the Youth Guarantee. The type of start-up support ranges from access to finance to so-called ‘soft’ support, which can include advice, coaching and skill development. </p><p>Although the Youth Guarantee has helped to place the existing measures under an overall youth employment strategy, more effort should be made to achieve a coordinated approach and greater complementarity across different types of interventions.  The bulk of the measures identified are stand-alone and small-scale, with limited financial resources. The European Social Fund and the Youth Guarantee are important to ensure that start-up measures for young people are linked more effectively with a national youth employment framework of integrated measures rather than left in a special category&nbsp;of their own.  </p><p>Despite the ever increasing policy interest in youth entrepreneurship, there seems to be very little appetite for comprehensive&nbsp;evaluations. There is often an over-reliance on lighter forms of evaluations based on simple take-up data or self-reported data of participants’ opinions and views. These disproportionately report more positive results than robust impact evaluations. The very few in-depth evaluations of start-up support measures for young people that have taken place so far point to limited or no impact.</p><p>There is a pressing need to design more evidence-based youth entrepreneurship policies. Sound and comprehensive impact evaluations can feed back into start-up programmes and make them more effective. This means that policy evaluation is not the end of the line, but rather an integrated and important&nbsp;part of youth emtrepreneurship&nbsp;policy delivery.   45082: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":29:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"45082\";s:3:\"url\";s:117:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/avoiding-the-quick-fix-approach-to-solving-youth-unemployment-45082\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-18 07:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-14 12:28:40\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-18 07:02:03\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:103:\"Download the report Start-up support for young people in the EU: From implementation to evaluation here\";s:3:\"url\";s:26:\"http://bit.ly/StartupYouth\";}}s:6:\"header\";s:61:\"Avoiding The Quick Fix Approach To Solving Youth Unemployment\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:6861:\"<p><i style=\"background-color: initial;\">This is a re-post of a blog piece&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/SEJStartUp\" target=\"_blank\">published on Social Europe (SE)</a></i><em>&nbsp;on 14 April.</em></p><p>by&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/SaraRisoMND\" target=\"_blank\">Sara Riso</a></p><p>A key priority for EU policy makers is to combat high levels of <a href=\"http://www.statista.com/statistics/266228/youth-unemployment-rate-in-eu-countries/\">youth unemployment</a>. Supporting young people to start a new business is increasingly regarded as a way to achieve this goal. And yet the understanding of what drives the success and failure of youth entrepreneurship policies remains incomplete. In a rush to deliver ‘quick fixes’ to the problem of youth unemployment, governments are falling short of devising well-coordinated policy interventions firmly grounded in evidence that could, in the longer term, be more effective and save public money<em>.</em></p><p>The most recent&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/StartupYouth\">Eurofound report</a> on start-up support for young people highlights the breadth and variety of publicly supported measures on youth entrepreneurship available in the EU. But it also points to the lack of robust policy impact evaluations and the many shortcomings of those evaluation practices deployed.</p><h2></h2><h2>Questioning The Rationale Of Youth Entrepreneurship Policies</h2><p>The point of departure of many start-up support measures under the <a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/social/main.jsp?catId=1079\">Youth Guarantee</a> is that entrepreneurship is a viable solution to youth unemployment. The assumption is that all young people are potential entrepreneurs. But the reality is different: very few make it and become successful entrepreneurs. Those who fail can instead end up scarred by failure.</p><p>The other problem is that many start-up support schemes under the Youth Guarantee are often general activation measures for the unemployed as a whole. The risk is of subsuming the young within a much broader target group without addressing their specific needs, and instead diminishing the potential impact of the interventions.</p><h2></h2><h2>The Bumpy Road From Conception To Evaluation Of Policy Interventions</h2><p>So where’s the rub? Where do policy makers get it wrong? It starts with the design of the interventions. First, the objectives of the interventions are rarely specified when programmes are being developed. Many start-up support measures specify higher-level aims, focused, for example, on increasing employability, but quantifiable and explicit targets are hardly ever set. This ends up compromising the entire evaluation process. In the absence of measurable targets, the evaluators have no other option than inferring and inputting them afterwards.</p><p>Another problem is that many start-up interventions for young people tend to be discrete, small-scale, temporary measures with relatively limited financial resources. They are rarely embedded within larger policy frameworks or youth employment strategies. Such measures are often short-lived and their potential impact is reduced. This is certainly not a good basis on which to build any evaluative research.</p><p>These first observations point to another important shortcoming: policy evaluations are not planned rigorously enough from the outset. They are often an exercise disconnected from the policy delivery, instead of being an integrated part of it and adequately resourced.</p><p>From a policy maker’s perspective, the big concern is the limited funds for policy evaluations, especially in a context where public funding is increasingly rationed. This concern is particularly important considering that impact evaluations using more sophisticated methods (those controlling for differences between the participants and non-participants) make heavy demands on time, as well as on human and financial resources. But what holds back from conducting impact evaluations, even more than any budgetary considerations, is that these costly endeavours often point to little or no effect of the policy measures under scrutiny.</p><h2></h2><h2>Evaluation Is An Iterative Process That Helps Designing Better Policies</h2><p>Then, if costly and sophisticated impact evaluations show little or no impact, why bother at all? Simpler monitoring-type evaluations, mainly relying on self-reported data of beneficiaries’ opinions and views or basic data on budget and uptake, are less costly and yield more positive results. These are still referred to as ‘evaluations’ in the policy jargon and they tend to be favoured over evaluations using more appropriate quantitative statistical methods.</p><p>This is evidenced by the very few youth entrepreneurship interventions that are the subject of robust impact evaluations compared to those that receive lighter forms of evaluation. A simpler evaluation of the UK’s <a href=\"https://www.princes-trust.org.uk/help-for-young-people/support-starting-business\">Prince’s Trust Enterprise Programme</a> (for disadvantaged youth) shows positive results and high satisfaction among participants. However, a previous evaluation adopting a more scientific approach pointed to very limited impact, especially in terms of employment probabilities.</p><p>The point of committing to and investing in more robust impact evaluations is to link the results to the process of delivering the policy measure. If no or limited policy impact is shown, this is not the end of the exercise. The evaluation should lead to changes in the way the measure is implemented. In practice, impact evaluations rarely indicate whether and how the measure should be modified or whether it should be halted altogether.</p><p>Although the evaluation of the French <a href=\"http://www.adie.org/nos-actions/Creajeunes-et-les-programmes-jeunes\">CréaJeunes</a> measure on enterprise training for young people found no policy impact, the programme continues to be run in the same format and is now part of the national Youth Guarantee. The results from this evaluation suggest that it may be wiser to revisit the specific design elements of the programme in order to improve its effectiveness and impact.</p><p>There is also evidence from a recent evaluation of the <a href=\"http://beta.ja-ye.org/Programmes/25/Company-Program_56.aspx\">Swedish Junior Achievement Company Programme</a> that offering hands-on opportunity to run a business at a fairly young age in a risk-free environment may be more effective. It helps young people to determine whether entrepreneurship is a suitable career path for them, without any fear of business failure.</p><p>If the results are not fed back into policy design and delivery, the risk is to perpetrate ineffective interventions that fail to address any youth problem and only waste public money.</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/i152losv9mbymssalykw.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/i152losv9mbymssalykw.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/i152losv9mbymssalykw.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/i152losv9mbymssalykw.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/i152losv9mbymssalykw.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/i152losv9mbymssalykw.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:3:{i:0;s:8:\"business\";i:1;s:13:\"labour market\";i:2;s:15:\"social policies\";}}s:8:\"subjects\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:7:\"subject\";a:5:{i:0;s:17:\"Employment issues\";i:1;s:7:\"Reports\";i:2;s:21:\"European Union issues\";i:3;s:15:\"Children, Youth\";i:4;s:19:\"Working   44849: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":28:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"44849\";s:3:\"url\";s:132:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/eurwork-blog-ireland-increases-minimum-wage-for-the-first-time-in-nine-years-44849\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-06 12:56:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-06 12:32:14\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-07 15:02:42\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:39:\"Photo © David Dennis, Creative Commons\";s:3:\"url\";s:48:\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/davidden/239581180\";}}s:6:\"header\";s:69:\"Ireland increases minimum wage to above 2007 level for the first time\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:5957:\"<p><em>The following article,&nbsp;originally&nbsp;written by&nbsp;Brian Sheehan from&nbsp;IRN Publishing for Eurofound's&nbsp;European Observatory of Working Life (EurWork), gives an overview of the reasons behind the&nbsp;decision to raise&nbsp;Ireland's National Minimum Wage (NMW) to above the 2007 level for the&nbsp;first time. The new rate&nbsp;was implemented on 1 January 2016, and followed on from a recommendation in the Low Pay Commission’s first annual report to increase the NMW by 50 cents per hour to a new hourly rate of €9.15.</em></p><p><em>To read the original article please go&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/IEWageRise\">http://bit.ly/IEWageRise</a>.</em></p><p>In January 2016 the&nbsp;then Minister for Business and Employment, Ged Nash, and the Minister for Skills, Research and Innovation, Damien English, welcomed the introduction of the new NMW rate, estimating that some 124,000 workers will benefit from the increase. Mr Nash said the increase to the NMW was the second one by the Fine Gael-Labour coalition Government during their term of office from 2011, because one of its first acts was to reverse a cut of €1 per hour to the minimum wage introduced by the previous government, adding that the increase will benefit a minimum wage worker by €60 a week, or more than €3,000 a year (when factoring in the reversal of the previous government's cut in the NMW).</p><p>Mr Nash explained that employers’ Pay Related Social Insurance (PRSI) thresholds were also adjusted from 1 January, ‘to ensure that an increased PRSI burden does not fall on minimum wage employers’. He said he was ‘acutely aware that the rising economic tide may not yet have reached every business’.</p><p>The decision to pay the increase follows the first report of the <a href=\"http://www.lowpaycommission.ie/\">Low Pay Commission</a>, an independent body tasked with considering the appropriate rate of the NMW. The Commission, which is made up of representatives from industry, workers and independent academic members, recommended the increase in July 2015. In its report, the Commission set out a range of data it had considered in recommending the 50 cent increase. However, three members of the Commission did not agree with the findings of the other members. Patricia King, the General Secretary of the Irish Congress of Trade Unions (ICTU); Gerry Light, Assistant General Secretary of the Mandate trade union; and Edel McGinley Director of the Migrant Rights Centre Ireland (MRCI) all called for the NMW to be increased to €10 an hour.</p><p>The Commission consulted with many interested parties before drawing up its report. In making its recommendation, the Commission set out a range of issues to consider, including:</p><ul> \n<li>evidence suggesting moderate increases will not lead to significant loss of jobs;</li><li>the Irish economy is recovering while still facing risks;</li><li>employment is increasing;</li><li>unemployment is high, but declining;</li><li>improved competitiveness (partly due to exchange rate movements);</li><li>while inflation has been low, the NMW has also largely remained unchanged for eight years.</li></ul><p>Mr Nash then asked the Commission to look at ‘sub-minima’ rates for younger workers and to consider why so many women are on the minimum wage. He said: ‘Given the preponderance of women in low paid jobs, I have asked the Low Pay Commission to help us come to a better understanding of why this is so, and what might be the underlying reasons for it.’ Sub-minima rates are paid to those under the age of 18; those still on their first or second year of work; and those undertaking training. <a href=\"http://www.lowpaycommission.ie/Rates/\">These rates</a> range from 70% to 90% of the NMW, but rise pro rata with the NMW increase from 1 January. The new minimum wage for workers aged under 18 is €6.41 per hour; those who are 18 or over and/or in their first year of work get €7.32 per hour; those who are over 18 and/or in their second year of work get €8.24 per hour. Trainee rates rise by the same percentage.</p><p>The Department of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation (DJEI)<a href=\"https://www.djei.ie/en/News-And-Events/Department-News/2016/January/04012016.html\"> opened a consultation with stakeholders </a> on a University of Limerick report that found that while so-called ‘zero-hours’ contracts are not used as extensively as had been feared, a new type of precarious work was becoming more common. Known as ‘if and when’ contracts, employers offer work if and when they have it available, and workers can choose to accept or refuse it. Due to the result of the recent Irish General Election, the outcome of the consultation, which closed in January, will now be a matter for the next government. </p><p>The decision by the UK Government to introduce a statutory living wage put this issue centre stage in the lead up to the election. The ICTU had already asked candidates and political parties in advance of the election, to pledge themselves to the introduction of a living wage of €11.50 an hour. The concept of the living wage is based on the estimated minimum amount an individual needs for his/her basic requirements. In the UK, Chancellor George Osborne announced in his summer budget of 2015 that the British Government was making its National Living Wage compulsory for workers over 25 years of age. The level of the wage is calculated by the government and is higher than the NMW. In Ireland, the level of the living wage has been estimated by groups such as trade unions to be  €11.50 per hour, but its implementation is entirely voluntary. A small number of non-union firms in Ireland, such as the supermarket chains Aldi and Lidl and the household goods firm IKEA, have announced the introduction of the living wage – all three companies have a very visible presence in Ireland. The NMW remains the statutory legal minimum in Ireland</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/cfgwx1ncgyiskhrscoax.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/cfgwx1ncgyiskhrscoax.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/cfgwx1ncgyiskhrscoax.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/cfgwx1ncgyiskhrscoax.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/cfgwx1ncgyiskhrscoax.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/cfgwx1ncgyiskhrscoax.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:2:{i:0;s:7:\"ireland\";i:1;s:12:\"minimum   44047: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":27:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"44047\";s:3:\"url\";s:122:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/international-women-s-day-2016-the-campaign-for-equality-continues-44047\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-03-08 09:38:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-03-08 09:29:04\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-03-08 09:54:45\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:0:\"\";s:3:\"url\";s:23:\"http://bit.ly/EFIWD2016\";}}s:6:\"header\";s:70:\"International Women's Day 2016 – The campaign for equality continues\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:4465:\"<p>Eurofound salutes<a href=\"http://www.internationalwomensday.com/\"> International Women’s Day</a> on 8 March, the theme of which is Pledge for Parity, highlighting persistent inequalities between the sexes in areas including politics, employment, education and health.</p><p>In Europe, equality between women and men at work is rising on some fronts, according to 2015 <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/resume/2015/working-conditions/first-findings-sixth-european-working-conditions-survey-resume\">findings from Eurofound’s European Working Conditions Survey (EWCS)</a>, but the gender gap continues in many areas. For instance, one-third of employees now have a woman supervisor, a rise from one-quarter in 2000, but closer analysis shows that while half of women are supervised by a woman, this is the case for only 15% of men.</p><p>Gender segregation in occupations is prevalent: four out of five jobs are dominated by one sex or the other. The map below shows the percentages of male workers per country who when asked 'Are workers with the same job title as you mostly men or women? ' answered 'Equal numbers of men and women'. The countries with the highest scores, and so the lowest occupational segregation, are Cyprus, Slovenia and Sweden; the ones with the most segregation are Estonia, Finland and Latvia.</p><p><a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/surveys/data-visualisation/sixth-european-working-conditions-survey-2015?locale=EN&amp;dataSource=EWCS2015&amp;media=png&amp;width=740&amp;question=Q22&amp;plot=heatMap&amp;countryGroup=linear&amp;subset=gender&amp;subsetValue=2--Male&amp;answer=1--Equal-numbers-of-men-and-women\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/DVS/render/?locale=EN&amp;dataSource=EWCS2015&amp;media=png&amp;width=740&amp;question=Q22&amp;plot=heatMap&amp;countryGroup=linear&amp;subset=gender&amp;subsetValue=2--Male&amp;answer=1--Equal-numbers-of-men-and-women\" style=\"border-style: solid; border-color: rgb(204, 204, 204); display: inline-block; float: none; margin: 20px 0px;\"></a></p><p>Unequal sharing of household and care work is the big issue outside of work. Women on average do 22 weekly hours of unpaid work in contrast to an average of 9 hours for men.</p><img alt=\"Composite indicator of paid and unpaid working hours of women and men, EWCS 2015\" src=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/sites/default/files/paid_and_unpaid_figure.png\" title=\"Composite indicator of paid and unpaid working hours of women and men, EWCS 2015\" style=\"border-style: solid; border-color: rgb(204, 204, 204); display: inline-block; float: none; margin: 20px 0px;\"><br>Source: <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/resume/2015/working-conditions/first-findings-sixth-european-working-conditions-survey-resume\">First findings: Sixth European Working Conditions Survey<p></p></a><p>There is also a big gap in employment between the sexes. In 2014, the employment rate for men of working age (15–64 years) was 70.1%; for women it was 59.6%. The gap exists in all Member States, varying between 1.5 percentage points in Finland to 25.6 percentage points in Malta. This employment gap comes with a price: in a forthcoming report, Eurofound estimates the cost of the gender employment gap in 2013 to amount to €370 billion, which is equal to 2.8% of EU GDP. </p><p>You can explore findings on gender imbalances at work and on other working conditions using Eurofound's <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/surveys/data-visualisation/sixth-european-working-conditions-survey-2015\">data visualisation tool</a> or find a range of other Eurofound outputs on gender equality: </p><ul><li><a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/2015/gender-equality-in-the-eu-priorities-for-eu-strategy-0\">Gender equality in the EU: Priorities for EU strategy</a>;  </li><li><a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/customised-report/2015/working-conditions-law-and-regulation/maternity-leave-provisions-in-the-eu-member-states-duration-and-allowances\">Maternity leave provisions in the EU Member States: Duration and allowances</a>;  </li><li><a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/report/2014/working-conditions-industrial-relations/social-partners-and-gender-equality-in-europe\">Social partners and gender equality in Europe</a>; </li><li><a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/topics/gender-gap-0\">European Observatory of Working LIfe (EurWORK )</a>.   43871: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":28:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"43871\";s:3:\"url\";s:134:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/the-importance-of-collective-bargaining-in-establishing-working-time-in-europe-43871\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-03-04 08:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-03-02 10:47:06\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-03-04 08:00:27\";s:6:\"header\";s:78:\"The importance of collective bargaining in establishing working time in Europe\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:6816:\"<p><em>In this blog piece Eurofound Research Officer&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/contact_people/jorge-cabrita-research-officer-44733\">Jorge Cabrita</a> looks at the key role of collective bargaining in establishing EU working time standards. This blog is a re-post from Social&nbsp;Europe, to view the original click&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/WorkTimeBlog\">here</a>.&nbsp;</em></p><p></p><p>Nowadays we all know that long or excessive working hours may have serious negative impacts on a person’s health and wellbeing. Eurofound‘s new report “Working time developments in the 21stcentury” suggests that if working time standards are mainly left to legislation or to be set unilaterally by employers, people will still tend to work longer hours. On the contrary, if the working time standards are negotiated through collective bargaining, the likely negative impact is less as people tend to work fewer hours on average.</p><p>It is exactly in recognition of those likely negative impacts on the health and wellbeing of workers that the European Working Time Directive came into being in 1993 through Council Directive 93/104/EC (as amended by the <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=celex:32000L0034\">Directive 2000/34/EC</a>) and consolidated ten years later by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/ALL/?uri=CELEX:32003L0088\">Directive 2003/88/EC</a>. It aims at guaranteeing minimum safety and health requirements for the organisation of working time by setting ‘minimum’ standards for working hours as well as ensuring that workers do not have to work excessive hours and are entitled to adequate rest and holidays. In attaining that objective, social partners can (and do!) have a very important role: in transposing the directive EU Member States don’t just introduce laws, regulations or other administrative provisions, they can also promote the application of collective agreements that are more favourable to the protection of workers’ health and safety.</p><p>In the EU member states, working time is regulated via different combinations of legislation and multi-layered collective bargaining and negotiations. Eurofound recently carried out a study looking at any changes in those national settings during the 15 years and focusing essentially on the settings applicable to the duration of work for full-time employees. We have identified four main working time setting regimes (see Figure 1 for a geographical representation):</p><ul><li>Pure mandated: Statutory legislation covers the majority of workers; collective bargaining and agreements covering working time duration or organisation are rare in this regime.</li><li>Adjusted mandated: Legislation plays a dominant role in regulating working time standards, but these are often adjusted through collective bargaining or negotiations at different levels.</li><li>Negotiated: Standards are set mainly by collective bargaining agreements, usually at sectoral level; such agreements may be complemented by company-level bargaining on working time organisation issues.</li><li>Unilateral: Statutory legislation plays hardly any role in the definition of working time standards and bargaining structures are highly decentralised; working time duration and organisation are usually stated in individual employment contracts, and tend to reflect the conditions determined and offered by employers.</li></ul><p></p><p>F<strong>igure 1 – Working time setting regimes in the EU</strong></p><p><img src=\"https://www.socialeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/worktime1.png\" alt=\"worktime1\" width=\"889\" height=\"773\" style=\"margin-bottom: 12px;\"><em>Source: Information from Eurofound’s network of European correspondents (2014-2015).</em></p><p>The findings show that more than two-thirds of Member States have an adjusted mandated or a negotiated working time setting regime, both of which imply the direct participation of social partners in how working time is defined. The eight Member States characterised by purely mandated regimes are all central and eastern European countries which joined the EU in or after 2004 (EU-13) and where collective bargaining structures are still evolving.</p><p>The working time setting regimes in the EU have remained essentially unchanged for the past 15 years and, in that context, the role of social partners in the definition of working time standards is essentially unchanged too. It is important to underline that this role appears decisive for the number of hours that workers usually work: these tend to be shorter in countries with negotiated or adjusted mandated regimes, and longer in the pure mandated and unilateral regimes (see Figure 2).</p><p></p><p><strong>Figure 2 – Average usual weekly working hours in the EU by working time setting regime</strong></p><p><img src=\"https://www.socialeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/worktime2.png\" alt=\"worktime2\" width=\"653\" height=\"393\" style=\"display: block; margin: 0px auto 24px;\">Source: Eurostat, Labour force survey, Eurofound calculations.</p><p>It seems that usual weekly working hours tend to be shorter where working time standards are predominantly defined through collective agreements. In other words, this means that collective bargaining over working time standards – in particular over working time duration – may have a sort of ‘cushion’ effect on working hours actually performed by workers. Furthermore, it seems clear that if working hours setting is mainly left to the employers, as in the unilateral regime of the UK, then actual working hours tend to be significantly longer. That is why Eurofound’s report underlines that if the definition of working time standards is put in terms of workers’ health and safety, the involvement of social partners is essential given the positive association of collective bargaining with shorter working hours and, therefore, a reduced impact of work on workers’ health and wellbeing.</p><p>Working time must, however, also be considered in terms of its organisation, which includes aspects such as regularity (same hours every day, same days every week, etc.), atypicality (working nights, weekends, very long working days, etc.), and flexibility (of starting and ending times, schedules, etc.) to fit in with the needs of both workers and organisations, which can be an extremely difficult task as those needs are typically divergent. But here again, social partners, as the collective representatives of employers and workers, can have a very important role in matching the needs of both and striking a balance which is beneficial for all.</p><p><em>The report “Working time developments in the 21st Century” is <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/\">now available from Eurofound</a>.</em></p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/dmwr2btpmzmq8yibnnb9.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/dmwr2btpmzmq8yibnnb9.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/dmwr2btpmzmq8yibnnb9.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/dmwr2btpmzmq8yibnnb9.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/dmwr2btpmzmq8yibnnb9.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/dmwr2btpmzmq8yibnnb9.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:5:{i:0;s:12:\"working   43439: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":27:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"43439\";s:3:\"url\";s:97:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/the-rise-of-temporary-contracts-in-europe-43439\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-02-19 08:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-02-16 15:54:25\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-02-19 08:00:53\";s:6:\"header\";s:41:\"The rise of temporary contracts in Europe\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:5700:\"<p></p><p></p><p><em>More than 1 in 10 employees in the EU are employed on temporary contracts, but a majority of them would prefer a permanent contract. Temporary contracts help employers to manage their labour demand, but there are downsides for employees, such as job insecurity and lower pay.</em></p><p>Temporary employment has been rising across many European countries for at least three decades. This is largely the result of reforms loosening employment protection legislation, which gives employers greater flexibility to adjust their workforces when their circumstances change, and reduces the cost. Workers on a temporary contract can be let go simply by non-renewal of their contracts, and the costs may be effectively zero; it can be much more difficult and costly to terminate permanent contracts.</p><p>The number of temporary employees grew by 25% in the EU27 between 2001 and 2012, compared with a growth rate of 7% in permanent employees. While this higher growth of temporary contracts occurred in two-thirds of EU countries, the absolute gains are largely attributable to five countries: Poland (2 million), Germany (1.1 million), Italy (900,000), France (400,000) and the Netherlands (300,000). However, Spain lost almost half a million temporary jobs in net terms in the same period, while the UK lost almost 140,000.</p><h2></h2><h2>Impact of the crash</h2><p>Temporary employment levels fell dramatically after the economic crash in 2008 as businesses that moved to reduce their workforces chose the non-renewal of temporary contracts as a first line of action. In Spain, temporary employees suffered the heaviest burden of the labour market adjustment, and their net numbers were reduced by 1.2 million between 2008 and 2012.</p><p>But the numbers bounced back quickly after the peak of the crisis. Uncertain of economic prospects, employers that needed to recruit opted for temporary employment to a much greater extent than previously: between 2010 and 2012, half of new recruits were hired on temporary contracts, compared with 40% in 2002. The proportion was around 80% in Spain and Poland.</p><p>In 2012, 13% of all employees across the EU27 were working under a temporary contract, compared with 11% in 2001. There is much variation in rates across EU countries as the figure below illustrates. Over a quarter of workers were on temporary contracts in Poland in 2012 and over one-fifth in Spain and Portugal, while rates were lower than 5% in Latvia, Bulgaria, Estonia, Lithuania and Romania.</p><p></p><p></p><h2><a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/file/lwe2015-figures5840image002png\">lwe_2015_-_figures_5840_image002.png</a></h2><img alt=\"Chart showing temporary employment rates in the EU27 over time \" title=\"Temporary employment rates in the EU27 over time\" height=\"433\" width=\"700\" src=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/sites/default/files/lwe_2015_-_figures_5840_image002.png\" style=\"border-style: none; display: inline-block; float: none; margin: 0px;\"><p></p><p><em>Source: European Union Labour Force Survey</em></p><h2></h2><h2>Involuntary temporary status</h2><p>Is there a problem with temporary employment? A recent report from Eurofound indicates there may be.</p><p>Firstly, most workers in the EU are temporary involuntarily – 64% say they are temporary because they could not find a permanent job – but transitioning out of temporary employment is not always easy. Between 2011 and 2012, just one in five temporary employees in the EU as a whole made that transition. A similar proportion moved into non-employment, while the equivalent figure for permanent employees was much lower (7%).</p><h2></h2><h2>Lower pay</h2><p>Secondly, temporary employees are paid less than their permanent counterparts, on average 19% less across European countries, according to Eurofound’s analysis of data from the 2010 Structure of Earnings Survey (SES). This negative wage gap exists across all 19 EU countries covered by the SES, apart from Estonia. It tends to be wider in those countries with a higher rate of temporary employment. The gap exists even when temporary employees are compared to permanent short-tenured employees across most countries, indicating that the lower wages for temporary employees are not only due to their shorter job tenures.</p><p>There is also a negative wage gap, of 14%, related to temporary status within the average company in all countries except Lithuania. This means temporary employees usually receive lower wages than their permanent counterparts due to pay differentials existing within companies and as well between companies, since temporary employees are more likely to work in those companies characterised by relatively lower pay levels.</p><h2></h2><h2>Labour market segmentation</h2><p>Several findings in the Eurofound report point towards the existence of labour market segmentation in some Member States; that is, the labour force tends to split into two segments, with limited mobility between them. One of the segments, where temporary employees are more likely to be found, is characterised by more job insecurity, poorer labour market prospects and lower pay levels, while the other segment, typically comprised of employees under permanent contracts, enjoys higher levels of job security, better pay and opportunities for career progression.</p><p>For more details on temporary employment in Europe and its characteristics, read the report <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/report/2015/labour-market/recent-developments-in-temporary-employment-employment-growth-wages-and-transitions\">Recent developments in temporary employment: Employment growth, wages and transitions</a>.</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/o4yzhdrf75li5gesnnsq.png\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/o4yzhdrf75li5gesnnsq.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/o4yzhdrf75li5gesnnsq.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/o4yzhdrf75li5gesnnsq.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/o4yzhdrf75li5gesnnsq.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/o4yzhdrf75li5gesnnsq.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:4:{i:0;s:20:\"comparative This article provides an overview of the minimum wage rates as of 1 January 2016, explains how they were set, and presents relevant discussions on minimum wages at national level.\";s:4:\"body\";s:1549:\"<p><strong>Eurofound has published a new article on the statutory minimum wage levels in Europe. This article provides an&nbsp;overview of the minimum wage rates as of 1 January 2016</strong><strong style=\"background-color: initial;\">, explains how they were set, and presents relevant discussions on minimum wages at national level.</strong></p><p>The article shows that the level of minimum wage greatly varies among EU countries. Bulgaria and Romania have the lowest minimum wage in the EU, while Luxembourg has the highest minimum wage – about nine times the Bulgarian rate. Changes to the minimum wage also vary significantly between countries; between January 2015 and January 2016 the highest increases of the minimum wage (by more than 10%) took place in Bulgaria, Estonia and Lithuania, whereas in Belgium and Greece the minimum wage has remained unchanged since 2012.</p><p>There are also considerable differences in the way countries establish minimum wage levels. In ten countries, the government determined the minimum wage following a (non-binding) recommendation of a third party – often the social partners or a tripartite body. In nine countries, the wage was set unilaterally by the government. A fixed rule for the determination of the minimum wage was used in five countries. In several countries, these ways of determination were combined. </p><p>To read the article in full go to&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/MinWageEU\">http://bit.ly/MinWageEU</a>, the article can also be downloaded via the PDF document
