  43071: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":30:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"43071\";s:3:\"url\";s:108:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/the-case-for-universal-support-for-european-families-43071\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-02-03 15:48:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-02-03 15:36:37\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-02-03 16:02:04\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";a:2:{i:0;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:97:\"Download the full report - Families in the economic crisis: Changes in policy measures in the EU'\";s:3:\"url\";s:28:\"http://bit.ly/CrisisFamilies\";}i:1;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:47:\"View the original blog piece on socialeurope.eu\";s:3:\"url\";s:24:\"http://bit.ly/SEFamilies\";}}}s:6:\"header\";s:52:\"The Case For Universal Support For European Families\";s:7:\"summary\";s:251:\"In this blog piece Daphne Ahrendt, Research Manager at Eurofound, analyses the new Families in the Economic Crisis report. She explains how the shift towards means tested support in Europe could be cutting off vital resources for struggling families. \";s:4:\"body\";s:8510:\"<p>by <a href=\"https://www.socialeurope.eu/author/daphne-arendt/\">Daphne Ahrendt</a> </p><p><strong>Austerity measures introduced during the crisis have disproportionately concerned cuts in the measures that are most vital for reducing child poverty: cash and tax benefits, a new Eurofound report shows. Furthermore, there has been a move away from universal coverage towards more targeted support. Of course, it makes good sense for governments to target spending on the most deprived families in a period of austerity. But at some point the pendulum can swing the wrong way and families that, under the principle of universality, were eligible for support may lose out, putting more families at risk of poverty than before.</strong></p><p>It should be said that the principle of universality prevailed during the crisis as universal cash benefits still represented more than half of the social expenditure on families in the EU, followed by universal benefits in-kind such as childcare services (the figures are for 2011, the latest year for which data was available at the time of writing the report). Means-tested cash benefits and means-tested benefits in-kind represented less than one-quarter of the total social expenditure on families. Although universal support remained the preferred approach over targeted help in most Member States, how countries support families varies strongly.</p><p>No surprises here: the three Nordic countries (Sweden, Finland and Denmark) did best. There, support for families was universal and Sweden and Finland offered families a perfect mix of cash and in-kind support (in Denmark the scale tipped in favour of universal in-kind benefits).</p><p>Table 1 shows the countries belonging to our four family policy country groups which Eurofound developed to account for large differences in family policy pathways in Europe. The countries belonging to Group 1 most enable families to move away from the traditional ‘breadwinner’ model, where it is the mother who stops working or reduces her hours to look after the children; in countries belonging to Group 4, family policies are most limiting in this regard.</p><p><em>Table 1: Eurofound family policy country groups</em></p><p><img src=\"https://www.socialeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/eurofound1-e1454276213219.png\" alt=\"eurofound\" width=\"750\" height=\"107\" style=\"display: block; margin: 0px auto 24px;\"></p><p>Figure 1 below shows the structure of social expenditure on families for these four groups of EU Member States. As can be seen, universal support is the norm in Group 1 countries with a good balance between cash and in-kind benefits. While universal support is also the norm in Group 2 countries, in-kind benefits are far less common and these countries are much more like the two groups with more limiting family policies.</p><p><em>Fig. 1: Structure of social expenditure on families by country groups (2011, %)</em></p><p><img src=\"https://www.socialeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/eurofound2-e1454276282997.png\" alt=\"eurofound2\" width=\"750\" height=\"763\" style=\"display: block; margin: 0px auto 24px;\"></p><p><em>Source: Own calculations based on ESSPROS</em></p><p>These expenditure patterns are to some degree mirrored in the extent to which different types of families report difficulties making ends meet. As figure 2 below shows, on average, the family types in the countries with more ‘enabling’ family policies (Groups 1 and 2) report fewer difficulties than those in the countries with more ‘limiting’ family policies (Groups 3 and 4).</p><p><em>Figure 2: ‘Difficulties making ends meet’ rate by family type and country group, 2012 (%)</em></p><p><img src=\"https://www.socialeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/eurfound3-e1454276340653.png\" alt=\"eurfound3\" width=\"750\" height=\"430\" style=\"display: block; margin: 0px auto 24px;\"></p><p>However, analyses from <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/european-quality-of-life-surveys-eqls\">Eurofound’s 2nd and 3rd wave of the European Quality of Life Survey</a> (fielded in 2007 and 2011/2012, providing insight into the economic and social changes occurring in Europe during the crisis) show that the share of lone parent families in Group 1 and Group 2 countries that reported difficulties making ends meet increased significantly (it doubled in Group 1 countries from 22% to 44% and rose from 37% to 50% in Group 2 countries). Although at 63% and 67%, respectively, the situation in Group 3 and Group 4 countries is still worse, the differences between more ‘enabling’ countries and more ‘limiting’ countries in 2012 are far less extreme than they were in 2007.</p><h2>The Case Of Finland</h2><p>What could explain this shift? One explanation lies in the change in policy pathways that is noted in some of the Group 1 countries. What’s happening in Finland provides some insights. After a number of expansionary measures that did not indicate an ‘austerity pathway’, the situation in Finland has recently changed. The low overall poverty rate among Finnish families is in part the outcome of a universal child benefit allowance that has long been viewed by experts and recipients alike as playing an important role in preventing it. The question is whether the low poverty rates in Finland will be maintained now that child benefit has been cut and the new government programme envisages further cutbacks in family policy. Experts expect the reductions to hit family income with higher poverty rates a likely outcome. This is aggravated by the fact that family transfers were not indexed until 2011, so their purchasing power had already declined. Already, there is some evidence in the statistics: the latest available Eurostat figures (2014) reveal a decrease in real gross disposable household income (GHDI).</p><h2>The Case For Universal Support</h2><p>At the same time, means-tested social assistance in Finland has gradually been increased since 2011. Research in Finland has found a link between the gradual increase in the amount of social assistance and the economic wellbeing of families in the lowest income quintile. This link suggests that these increases have been an effective countermeasure to poverty among the lowest income families.</p><p>Whilst means-tested support is a good way to help the most vulnerable, the trend among EU Member States to move away from universal support and towards more targeted support needs to be monitored precisely because of what is happening in Finland. The changes there represent a major shift in policy orientation. The Finnish proposal to restrict entitlement to public childcare is further evidence of this shift.</p><h2>Work-life Balance Initiatives Are Less Affected</h2><p>Eurofound’s report also contains good news: during the crisis years the focus on work-life balance has been maintained. The report, which looks at what countries did for European families since 2010 in response to the crisis, highlights that across the EU measures have been introduced to help people better combine work and family life. Several examples of these good practices are identified: e.g. the daycare centre and kindergarten funding scheme set up in Greece to provide affordable childcare service, the expansion of childcare services in Poland and new variants introduced in Austria giving parents more options to take parental leave. Aside from these work-life balance measures, the report identifies a number of other policy measures that appear to work in avoiding poverty or social exclusion for families with dependent children.</p><h4></h4><h4>About Daphne Ahrendt</h4><p>Daphne Ahrendt joined Eurofound’s Living Conditions and Quality of Life Unit as a research manager in January 2013. Her current research activities focus on families in the economic crisis, social mobility and in-work poverty. She is also involved in preparing the fourth wave of the European Quality of Life Survey, which she has worked with since 2003, contributing to the design of the questionnaire and the management of the survey.</p><ul>\n<li>This article was originally posted on socialeurope.eu on 1 February, go to&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/SEFamilies\">http://bit.ly/SEFamilies</a> to view the original</li><li>Read in-depth&nbsp;how families have been affected by the economic crisis in the new report ‘Families in the economic crisis: Changes in policy measures in the EU’:&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/CrisisFamilies\">http://bit.ly/CrisisFamilies</a></li></ul>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/xxagtjlggn2aiuishuuh.png\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/xxagtjlggn2aiuishuuh.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/xxagtjlggn2aiuishuuh.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/xxagtjlggn2aiuishuuh.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/xxagtjlggn2aiuishuuh.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/xxagtjlggn2aiuishuuh.jpg\";s:12:\"attached_pdf\";s:69:\"http://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/nqyqnd5kwpx4yju4shuv.pdf\";s:21:\"attached_pdf_filename\";s:56:\"The   41756: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":26:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"41756\";s:3:\"url\";s:131:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/addressing-the-employment-and-social-consequences-of-mobility-and-migration-41756\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2015-12-11 10:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2015-12-10 16:35:21\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2015-12-11 10:00:23\";s:6:\"header\";s:75:\"Addressing the employment and social consequences of mobility and migration\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:10621:\"<p><em>Eurofound has been doing extensive work on the issues of mobility and migration. This blog gives a brief overview of the different aspects of EU mobile workers, posted workers and third-country migration, as well as a preview of our upcoming research.</em></p><h2>Free movement in the EU</h2><p>All citizens of EU Member States are entitled to live, work and study in another Member State. The right to free movement derives from the concept of EU citizenship, which was laid down in the Maastricht Treaty (the Treaty on European Union) of 1992.</p><p>Certain rules and conditions qualify this right, however, depending on the status of the individual.</p><ul> \n<li>Workers and their immediate family members have the right to reside in another Member State without any conditions or formalities.</li><li>Job-seekers have the right to reside without any conditions for a period of six months and even longer if they continue to look for work and have a ‘genuine chance’ of securing it.</li><li>Individuals who are not economically active – including students, retirees and unemployed people – can reside without conditions for three months. After that, they can continue to reside if they have sufficient financial means so as not to become a burden on the host country’s social assistance and health systems.</li></ul><p>Over 14 million EU citizens live in a Member State that is not their home country. In EU communications, these are known as ‘mobile EU citizens’. Those who settle at least semi-permanently in the destination country can be considered as internal migrants within the EU.</p><h2></h2><h2>EU mobile workers</h2><p>Most mobile EU citizens avail of free movement in order to work. Free movement of workers is a pillar of the single market and has been a principle since the beginning of the European project, set down in the 1958 Treaty of Rome. EU law establishes their right to equal treatment regarding access to employment, pay, working conditions and certain social benefits.</p><p>The main internal migration flow within the EU is from east to west; workers from the central and eastern European Member States are attracted by the availability of work in the pre-2004 Member States (the EU15), as well as the higher pay and better working conditions. Nevertheless, mobility overall is low and has always been so, even during the pre-crisis economic boom, something the European Commission is committed to changing.</p><p>The Commission considers intra-EU mobility to be a means of addressing demand for skilled labour and tackling bottlenecks in filling vacancies, thereby contributing to economic growth across the Union. The Europe 2020 flagship initiative ‘An agenda for new skills and jobs’ identifies labour mobility as one of the means to ‘modernise labour markets and empower people by developing their skills throughout the lifecycle with a view to increase labour market participation and better match labour supply and demand’. A labour mobility package is forthcoming, with the aim of supporting the movement of workers while dealing with abuses.</p><p>Analysis of <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/report/2014/eu-member-states/labour-market-social-policies/labour-mobility-in-the-eu-recent-trends-and-policies\">recent trends in labour mobility between Member States</a> shows that the economic crisis temporarily stalled mobility as unemployment spiralled across the EU15. At the same time, the crisis <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/report/2012/labour-market-social-policies/labour-mobility-within-the-eu-the-impact-of-return-migration\">did not lead to the expected mass return of mobile workers</a> to their home countries. Movement of workers across borders rebounded quickly once the peak crisis period had passed, although mobility rates remain lower than before the crisis.</p><h2></h2><h2>Posted workers</h2><p>A separate group of workers who cross borders within the EU are posted workers, who are employed in one EU Member State but sent by their employer to work in another Member State on a temporary basis. Posting has grown as a result of the transnational provision of services but has given rise to concerns about working conditions and social dumping, the practice of employers hiring migrant workers to work more cheaply than local workers. The Posting of Workers Directive aims to tackle these issues. Eurofound has examined the<a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/report/2010/working-conditions-industrial-relations/posted-workers-in-the-european-union\"> extent of posting of workers in Europe</a>, including the role of EU and national legislation and collective bargaining in determining the employment and working conditions of posted workers.</p><h2></h2><h2>Third-country migration</h2><p>In the context of the EU, third-country migration refers to the movement of non-EU nationals into the EU – this includes refugees and asylum seekers, as well as those migrating for other reasons. The Commission’s new <a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/home-affairs/what-we-do/policies/european-agenda-migration/index_en.htm\">European Agenda on Migration</a> outlines the EU’s immediate response to the migration and refugee crisis in the Mediterranean.</p><p>In the medium term, it also aims to develop a new policy on legal migration, recognising that migration has to be part of the EU strategy to address shortages of specific skills and the challenges presented by demographic ageing. Integration of third-country nationals is a challenge for Member States, especially given the frequent mismatch between these migrants’ skills and the labour market needs. Member States that have the best outcomes have been found to be those that focus on <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/report/2015/labour-market-social-policies/challenges-of-policy-coordination-for-third-country-nationals\">coordinating integration and labour market policies from the outset</a>.</p><h2></h2><h2>Integration</h2><p>Many of the challenges of integration are dealt with at the local level, where cities and local authorities have a central role in implementing integration policies and in developing innovative approaches to housing, education and cultural diversity.</p><p>Between 2006 and 2010, Eurofound carried out a series of projects with a network of 30 European cities to support local integration policies for migrants (<a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/clip-european-network-of-cities-for-local-integration-policies-for-migrants\">CLIP</a>). This network aimed to deliver more effective integration policy through the structured sharing of experiences. The project resulted in recommendations for local, national and European policymakers in four policy areas: <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/clip-housing-and-integration-of-migrants-in-europe\">housing and integration of migrants</a>; <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/clip-equality-and-diversity-in-jobs-and-services\">equality and diversity in jobs and services</a>; <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/clip-intercultural-policies-in-european-cities\">intercultural policies</a>; and <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/clip-ethnic-entrepreneurship\">ethnic entrepreneurship</a>.</p><h2></h2><h2>Concerns around mobility</h2><p>In promoting intra-EU mobility, the Commission simultaneously supports Member States in fighting abuse of the right to free movement. One such abuse is social dumping, noted above. Most EU15 Member States have implemented policy measures to prevent social dumping. Some have introduced intensified tax, wage and work environment inspections in companies in order to secure compliance with national labour market regulations.</p><p>Public debate on mobility and migration in the destination countries often centres on the issue of ‘welfare tourism’ – the premise that citizens of less prosperous countries move to the EU15 principally to avail of more generous social welfare benefits, putting significant strain on public services and social welfare budgets. Research, however, has debunked this claim. Eurofound’s research on the <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/report/2015/labour-market-social-policies/social-dimension-of-intra-eu-mobility-impact-on-public-services\">social dimension of intra-EU mobility</a> found that mobile EU citizens from central and eastern European Member States claim benefits to a lesser extent than natives, supporting other research findings that non-nationals make a positive contribution overall to a country’s finances.</p><p>From the other perspective, that of the countries of origin, the large outflows of workers have led to substantial population loss over the years, threatening already precarious demographic balances, as there is no replacement for their ageing workforces. The loss of skilled workers, such as <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/report/2013/labour-market-social-policies/mobility-and-migration-of-healthcare-workers-in-central-and-eastern-europe\">health professionals</a>, has a detrimental effect on the provision of services and on the economic potential of these countries.</p><h2></h2><h2>Forthcoming Eurofound work</h2><p>Eurofound’s plans for research in the area of mobility and migration in 2016 include the following:</p><ul> \n<li>publication of the findings of a study on the regulation of labour market intermediaries and the role of the social partners in preventing trafficking of labour;</li><li>a project that aims to provide a more detailed, accurate and comparable picture of migration and geographic mobility than has ever been previously available in Europe;</li><li>an examination of fraudulent forms of contracting work that intentionally circumvent existing regulations, which will also look at how these operate in connection with cross-border mobility;</li><li>a mapping of the current legal framework, systems and processes for labour market integration of refugees in the Member States.</li></ul><p>Visit our <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/news/spotlight-on/mobility-and-migration/resources-key-eurofound-reports-and-other-resources-on-mobility-and-migration\">key resources on mobility and migration</a> to explore the topic further.  </p><p>This area of Eurofound's work is aligned particularly with the cluster theme <em>Mobility and migration – addressing employment and social consequences</em> in its <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/htmlfiles/ef1252.htm\">four-year work programme 2013–2016</a>.</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/l6fn8bppf8soae7kdcjk.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/l6fn8bppf8soae7kdcjk.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/l6fn8bppf8soae7kdcjk.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/l6fn8bppf8soae7kdcjk.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/l6fn8bppf8soae7kdcjk.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/l6fn8bppf8soae7kdcjk.jpg\";s:8:\"subjects\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:7:\"subject\";a:10:{i:0;s:17:\"Employment   41420: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":26:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:9:\"blog_post\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:5:\"41420\";s:3:\"url\";s:116:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/blog_posts/working-time-clashes-with-work-life-balance-for-many-workers-41420\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2015-11-30 17:22:13\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2015-11-30 17:22:13\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2015-11-30 17:22:16\";s:6:\"header\";s:62:\"Working time clashes with work–life balance for many workers\";s:7:\"summary\";s:346:\"​Despite increasing sophistication of work organisation and the development of ICT tools with the aim of making the workplace more efficient, long working time continues to be a fact of life for many workers, according to the last findings on working conditions in Europe from Eurofound. To download the report go to http://bit.ly/Resume6EWCS. \";s:4:\"body\";s:4155:\"<p><strong>Despite increasing sophistication of work organisation and the development of ICT tools with the aim of making the workplace more efficient, long working time continues to be a fact of life for many workers, according to the last findings on working conditions in Europe from Eurofound.</strong></p><p>Although the length of working time has been falling for decades, many workers still put in more than the standard 40-hour week: 1 in 4 male employees and 1 in 10 female employees, in fact.</p><p>These figures, however, pale in comparison with the figures for people who run their own business. Among the self-employed who employ others, 62% of men and 41% of women work 48 hours or more a week. The figures are only slightly less striking for self-employed who work on their own, with 38% of men and 27% of women working 48 hours or more. These are sobering statistics for anyone thinking of starting their own business.</p><h2>Outside the 9 to 5</h2><p>Working outside the 9 to 5 weekday is a feature of working life for a significant segment of the workforce in Europe. One-third of all workers (32%) work days of 10 hours or more at least once month. More than half of workers (52%) work at least one Saturday per month, while almost one-third (30%) work a least one Sunday. Around a fifth do shift work (21%) and night work (19%). </p><h2></h2><p><img alt=\"Chart showing percentage of workers working atypical hours, 2000–2015\" title=\"Percentage of workers working atypical hours, 2000–2015\" height=\"489\" width=\"700\" src=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/sites/default/files/image004.png\" style=\"border-style: none; display: inline-block; float: none; margin: 0px;\"></p><p>Are workers happy with the length of their working hours? The majority (58%) say that their working time is in line with their preferences, but over a quarter (28%) would decrease their working hours if they had a free choice and doing so were compatible with making a living.</p><h2>Eating into private life</h2><p>Work is regularly seeping into private life as workers work on their own time to keep up. Nearly half (45%) say that they have worked in their free time in the past year in order to meet work demands, with 3% doing this on a daily basis, 7% several times a week and 13% several times a month. </p><p>Work encroaches on private life in other ways, too: 14% spend a substantial amount of their spare time worrying about work, while 21% feel too tired to do some of the household jobs that need to be done. One in ten reports that their job frequently prevents them from devoting time to their family. </p><p>The reverse – private life encroaching on work – is much less prevalent, with just 3% of workers reporting that family and care responsibilities have a negative impact on their job. </p><h2>Regularity and predictability</h2><p>Having regular and predictable working hours is important for reconciling work with the commitments of life outside work, but one-third of workers (30%) have to deal with low regularity. Working time arrangements change regularly for 31% of employees, often at short notice: 5% are informed about the change on the same day and 8% the day before. </p><p>These findings suggest that the balance between work and private life is weighing heavily on the work side for considerable numbers of workers. They also raise health and safety concerns as long hours, night work and shift work are associated with increased risk of accidents at work and poorer health in the long term. Doubt has also been raised <a href=\"http://ftp.iza.org/dp8129.pdf\">whether long working hours are beneficial to the economy</a> in terms of increased productivity. </p><p>The latest findings on working time and other working conditions can be found in the <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/resume/2015/working-conditions/first-findings-sixth-european-working-conditions-survey-resume\">résumé of the sixth European Working Conditions Survey</a> and Eurofound's interactive <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/surveys/data-visualisation/sixth-european-working-conditions-survey-2015\">survey mapping tool</a>.</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/hd3456uojt1rbbtnbs0f.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/hd3456uojt1rbbtnbs0f.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/hd3456uojt1rbbtnbs0f.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/hd3456uojt1rbbtnbs0f.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/hd3456uojt1rbbtnbs0f.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/hd3456uojt1rbbtnbs0f.jpg\";s:8:\"subjects\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:7:\"subject\";a:10:{i:0;s:17:\"Employment   2318971: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":29:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:7:\"2318971\";s:3:\"url\";s:171:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/quality-of-life-improving-in-europe-but-progress-undermined-by-persisting-inequalities-and-growing-uncertainty-2318971\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2017-12-07 09:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2017-12-06 09:40:35\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2017-12-07 09:00:31\";s:6:\"header\";s:111:\"Quality of life improving in Europe, but progress undermined by persisting inequalities and growing uncertainty\";s:7:\"summary\";s:371:\"Results from Eurofound’s 2016 European Quality of Life Survey (EQLS) show general progress in the three key areas - quality of life, quality of society and quality of public services. Nevertheless, there remain signs of persisting inequalities and rising uncertainties in some areas with particular differences apparent between countries, gender, age and income groups.\";s:4:\"body\";s:4065:\"<p><strong style=\"background-color: initial;\">Results from Eurofound’s 2016 European Quality of Life Survey (EQLS) show general progress in the three key areas - quality of life, quality of society and quality of public services. Since the 2011 survey, levels of optimism are up, satisfaction with living standards has increased and some other quality of life indicators are back to pre-crisis levels. Nevertheless, there remain signs of persisting inequalities and rising uncertainties in some areas with particular differences apparent between countries, gender, age and income groups.</strong></p><p>‘We have seen improvements for many, although from low points following the economic crisis,’ said <strong>Juan Menéndez-Valdés</strong>, Eurofound’s Director. ‘Indeed, in some cases, the indicators display a return to pre-crisis levels – reflecting, in part, the general economic upturn and return to growth across the Member States.’</p><p>Similarly quality of society dimensions have seen an improvement with generally increased trust in national institutions and a decline in feelings of social exclusion. Satisfaction with living standards has increased in a majority of Member States and more people can now make ends meet than was the case in 2011. Ratings for key public services have also increased overall. </p><p>While a number of countries, mostly in central and eastern Europe, continue to catch up, others have stalled in the process of upward convergence. Satisfaction with living standards, for example, increased particularly in Bulgaria, Estonia, Hungary, Ireland and Poland, but life satisfaction declined in Croatia, Cyprus, Greece, Italy and Spain. There are also still profound inequalities across different gender, age and income groups.</p><p>‘Despite growth that has seen fewer people reporting material hardship compared to five years ago, over half of the population in 11 Member States still say they have difficulties making ends meet,’ said <strong>Robert Anderson</strong>, Head of Unit, Social Policies, at Eurofound.</p><p>The EQLS presents data on issues that general statistics do not cover – such as the perceived quality of society, trust in institutions and societal tensions. It looks at a range of issues, such as housing, deprivation, family, health and participation in society. It also covers subjective topics, such as people’s levels of happiness, how satisfied they are with their lives, work-life balance and social exclusion. The EQLS 2016 has a specific focus on the quality of public services and life online in terms of using online services and experiences on the web. In-depth and comparative data are available for everyone to access via the <a href=\"https://www.eurofound.europa.eu/eqls2016?utm_source=mynewsdesk&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_campaign=quality-of-life-and-public-services&amp;utm_content=eqls%20interactive%20page\" target=\"_blank\">EQLS Interactive page</a>, which gives a detailed picture of quality of life, no matter where you live in the EU. </p><p><strong><br></strong></p><p><strong>GET IN-DEPTH</strong></p><ul>\n<li>Access in-depth information on quality of life in Europe, across all EU Member States and in all official languages via our <a target=\"_blank\">European Quality of Life Survey 2016 Interactive page</a>\n</li>\n<li>Need more analysis of the data?\_Read the blog\_<a href=\"https://twitter.com/eurofound\" target=\"_blank\">Eurofound's page</a> and via #4EQLS</li>\n</ul>\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:1564:\"<p><strong><br></strong></p><p><strong>ABOUT out in September 2016 – February 2017 in the EU28 and the five candidate countries (Albania, fYR Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia and Turkey). This unique, pan-European survey examines both the objective circumstances of citizens' lives as well as how they feel about those circumstances and their lives in general, creating a rich data source on the quality of life of the people in Europe. Upward convergence in the EU </strong></p><p>#DublinForum17</p><p>14 - 15 November 2017, Dublin Castle, Ireland </p><p>The Foundation Forum is Eurofound’s flagship event, aimed at reaching high-level policymakers in the field of social, employment and work-related policies. </p><p>The theme of the <a href=\"https://www.eurofound.europa.eu/events/foundation-forum-2017?utm_source=mynewsdesk&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_campaign=corporate&amp;utm_content=foundation%20forum%202017\">Foundation Forum 2017</a> is on various perspectives of convergence in Europe. can now download the\_</strong><a background paper</a><strong>\_and other related material. </strong></p><p>The Foundation Forum 2017 takes place just two days before the <a href=\"https://www.socialsummit17.se/\">Social Summit 2017</a>, where all EU Heads of State or Government will gather in Gothenburg, Sweden to discuss fair jobs and growth, and adopt the formal proclamation of the European Pillar of Social Rights.   1806945: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":30:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:7:\"1806945\";s:3:\"url\";s:191:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/working-anytime-anywhere-the-effects-on-the-world-of-work-new-report-highlights-opportunities-and-challenges-of-expanding-telework-1806945\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2017-02-15 12:10:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2017-02-15 06:10:37\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2017-04-20 12:20:06\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:29:\"Download the report from here\";s:3:\"url\";s:26:\"http://bit.ly/tictm2017gen\";}}s:6:\"header\";s:141:\"‘Working anytime, anywhere: The effects on the world of work’ - new report highlights opportunities and challenges of expanding telework \";s:7:\"summary\";s:379:\"The expanding use of digital technologies such as smartphones, tablets, laptops and desktop computers for work for home and elsewhere is rapidly transforming the traditional model of work. It can improve work-life balance, reduce commuting time, and boost productivity, but it can also potentially result in longer working hours, higher work intensity and work-home interference.\";s:4:\"body\";s:4359:\"<p><strong style=\"background-color: initial;\">GENEVA/BRUSSELS (ILO News) –The expanding use of digital technologies such as smartphones, tablets, laptops and desktop computers for work for home and elsewhere is rapidly transforming the traditional model of work. It can improve work-life balance, reduce commuting time, and boost productivity, but it can also potentially result in longer working hours, higher work intensity and work-home interference, according to a new joint ILO-Eurofound report released today.</strong></p><p>The new report <em><a href=\"http://bit.ly/tictm2017gen\" target=\"_blank\">Working anytime, anywhere: The effects on the world of work</a> </em>synthesises research carried out by both organisations in 15 countries, including ten EU Member States<a>[1]</a> as well as Argentina, Brazil, India, Japan and the United States. The study identifies several types of employees using new technologies to work outside the employer’s premises, including regular home-based teleworkers, workers performing occasional telework and ICT-mobile work (T/ICTM).<a>[2]</a></p><p>The report highlights a number of positive effects of T/ICTM work, such as greater working time autonomy leading to more flexibility in terms of working time organisation, and reduced commuting time resulting in a better overall work-life balance and higher productivity. It also identifies several disadvantages such as a tendency to work longer hours, and an overlap between paid work and personal life – which can lead to high levels of stress. The report draws clear distinctions between home-based teleworkers who seem to enjoy better work-life balance and ‘high-mobile’ workers who are more at risk of negative health and well-being outcomes.</p><p>‘This report shows that the use of modern communication technologies facilitates a better overall work-life balance but, at the same time, also blurs the boundaries between work and personal life, depending on the place of work and the characteristics of different occupations,’ said the ILO’s <strong>Jon Messenger</strong>, co-author of the report. </p><p>The report provides recommendations in order to address this disparity, such as promoting formal part-time teleworking to help teleworkers maintain ties with their co-workers and improve worker well-being, while restricting informal and supplemental T/ICTM work involving long working hours.</p><p>‘It is particularly important to address the issue of supplemental work performed through modern communications technology, for example additional working from home, which could be viewed as unpaid overtime, and also to ensure that minimum rest periods are respected, in order to avoid negative effects on workers’ health and well-being,’ said <strong>Oscar Vargas </strong>from Eurofound.</p><p>Currently only the EU has an overall framework to adapt to digital change on telework, with the <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=URISERV%3Ac10131\">European Framework Agreement on Telework</a>.  However, most existing initiatives are related to formal, home-based telework, while problems seem to be more recurrent with informal, occasional T/ICTM work. </p><p>As telework becomes more prominent so too has the need to disconnect in order to separate paid work and personal life, with France and Germany beginning to look at arrangements at the company level, and at existing and new legislation. In the future this may result in concrete measures to make working life less pervasive, such as shutting down computer servers outside working hours in order to prevent emails during rest times and holidays, which is already happening in some companies.</p><p><a href=\"http://bit.ly/tictm2017gen\" target=\"_blank\"><strong>Download the report from here</strong></a></p><p><a>[1]</a>Belgium, France, Finland, Germany, Hungary, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, and the United Kingdom</p><p><a>[2]</a>The incidence of T/ICTM varies substantially, ranging from 2 per cent to 40 per cent of employees, and depending on the country, occupation, sector and the frequency with which employees engage in the type of work. Across the EU-28, an average of about 17 per cent of employees are engaged in T/ICTM. In most countries, larger proportions of workers carry out T/ICTM occasionally rather than on a regular basis.</p>\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:1319:\"<p><strong>ABOUT EUROFOUND</strong></p><p>For more information about Eurofound and its work,\nand free access to all our data and findings, visit our <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu\" style=\"font-size: 13px;\">website</a> and follow us on style=\"font-size: 13px;\">LinkedIn</a>, and&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.facebook.com/eurofound.europa.eu\" style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Facebook</a>.&nbsp;</p><p>For upcoming publications and events please see our&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.eurofound.europa.eu/eurofound-calendar-2017-events-and-publications\" target=\"_blank\">Corporate Calendar 2017</a>.</p><p><strong>ABOUT THE INTERNATIONAL LABOUR ORGANISATION (ILO)</strong></p><p>The only tripartite U.N. agency, since 1919 the ILO brings together governments, employers and workers representatives of <a href=\"http://www.ilo.org/public/english/standards/relm/country.htm\">187 member States</a>, to set labour standards, develop policies and devise programmes promoting decent work for all women and men.</p><p>Click here for more <a href=\"http://www.ilo.org/global/about-the-ilo/newsroom/lang--en/index.htm\">news and information</a> from the ILO</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/iqmd7q3koy9pbjfr6s4a.png\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/iqmd7q3koy9pbjfr6s4a.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/iqmd7q3koy9pbjfr6s4a.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/iqmd7q3koy9pbjfr6s4a.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/iqmd7q3koy9pbjfr6s4a.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/iqmd7q3koy9pbjfr6s4a.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:5:{i:0;s:20:\"comparative This document sets out the activities the Agency plans to undertake in the next four years to support European decision-makers in formulating effective policies for the improvement of quality of life and work in a fair and competitive Europe during this challenging period.\";s:4:\"body\";s:3141:\"<p><strong>(Dublin, Ireland): Eurofound has launched its <a href=\"http://bit.ly/Programme2017-2020\">new work programme</a> for 2017 to 2020. This document sets out the activities the Agency plans to undertake in the next four years to support European decision-makers in formulating effective policies for the improvement of quality of life and work in a fair and competitive Europe during this challenging period.</strong><strong></strong></p><p>The new multiannual programme commences at a time when the EU looks back at a decade of economic and political turmoil. A large part of Europe has experienced high levels of unemployment, especially among young people, growing economic insecurity, and increasing poverty and exclusion. While slow growth returned to most Member States in 2015, and employment levels recovered in many, the recovery is fragile and significant divides persist both within and between Member States. These tensions affect European integration.&nbsp;It is important therefore that in the coming period progress is made in solving the economic challenges Europe continues to face: increasing competitiveness; ensuring sustainable, job-rich growth; achieving more equal and inclusive societies. </p><p>In response, Eurofound has chosen six strategic areas of intervention in which to carry out activities aimed at providing the knowledge to achieve upward convergence of living and working conditions in the European Union. </p><ul> \n<li><a href=\"http://bit.ly/working-conditions\"><strong>Working conditions and sustainable work</strong></a><strong></strong></li><li><a href=\"http://bit.ly/industrial-relations\"><strong>Industrial relations</strong></a><strong></strong></li><li><a href=\"http://bit.ly/labour-market-change\"><strong>Labour market change</strong></a><strong></strong></li><li><a href=\"http://bit.ly/qol-public-services\"><strong>Quality of life and public services</strong></a><strong></strong></li><li><a href=\"http://bit.ly/the-digital-age\"><strong>The digital age: Opportunities and challenges for work and employment</strong></a><strong></strong></li><li><a href=\"http://bit.ly/monitoring-convergence\"><strong>Monitoring convergence in the European Union</strong></a><strong></strong></li></ul><p>Through the framework of these six areas – including both established areas of expertise and new and innovative dimensions - Eurofound aims to examine how living and working conditions can be improved through public policies and legislation, through the intervention of the social partners, and through practices at workplace level.</p><p>Eurofound Director <strong>Juan Menéndez-Valdés</strong> noted that the programming document ‘will guide Eurofound’s work and shape its contribution during this period in developing scientifically sound, unbiased, timely and relevant knowledge to support policymakers in the EU institutions, social partners and national governments’.</p><p><strong>Download Eurofound’s new four-year work programme here:   1652830: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":30:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:7:\"1652830\";s:3:\"url\";s:126:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/new-survey-shines-spotlight-on-increasingly-complex-world-of-work-1652830\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-11-17 08:10:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-11-16 13:52:11\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2017-01-16 12:04:19\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";a:2:{i:0;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:145:\"​Click here for more information on the sixth European Working Conditions Survey, including access to the comprehensive data visualisation tool\";s:3:\"url\";s:23:\"http://bit.ly/6EWCS2015\";}i:1;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:90:\"Click here to download the ​sixth European Working Conditions Survey – Overview report\";s:3:\"url\";s:25:\"http://bit.ly/6EWCSReport\";}}}s:6:\"header\";s:66:\"New survey shines spotlight on increasingly complex world of work \";s:7:\"summary\";s:122:\"The overview report of the pan-European sixth European Working Conditions Survey #6EWCS is launched today 17 November 2016\";s:4:\"body\";s:4140:\"<p><strong></strong><strong>(Dublin, Ireland): New technologies, labour market segmentation and a blurring of work and private life are making the world of work ever more complex.  This is the background against which the overview report of the pan-European&nbsp;</strong><a href=\"http://bit.ly/6EWCSReport\" target=\"_blank\">sixth European Working Conditions Survey</a><strong>&nbsp;is launched at the European Parliament in Brussels today.  It shows an increasingly skilled workforce, largely satisfied with work, enjoying improved working time arrangements and greater equality between women and men. But beneath the surface is a diverse and heterogeneous labour market, where one in five workers has a poor quality job.</strong></p><p>For example, the report reveals that while there has been some improvement in the physical environment index, a significant proportion of workers still remains exposed to physical risks in their jobs - in particular posture-related risks (62%) - while adverse social behaviour is experienced by 16% of workers and more than one third of workers report some or great difficulty in making ends meet. Almost two in five workers (37%) in the EU work to tight deadlines all or most of the time, while one in three reports working at high speed all of the time or almost all of the time. Lines between work and home life are also increasingly blurred, with one in five (22%) workers reporting that they work outside of working hours several times per month in order to meet demands. </p><p>In order to capture the diversity of what it means to work in Europe, the EWCS clustered jobs into five distinct groups. One in five workers has a poor quality job with disadvantageous job quality features and job holders tending to have a low level of education and reporting an unsatisfactory experience of working life. 13% of workers in Europe have under pressure jobs where, despite scoring positively in terms of earnings, skills use and prospects, they have poorer levels of social support, higher incidence of adverse social behaviour, and high work intensity. Around a quarter of workers have a smooth running job where most dimensions of job quality are satisfactory. One in five workers has an active manual job, which has a good social environment, prospects and earnings, but high physical demands and work intensity. Finally, one in five workers has a high flying job which, except for work intensity and longer working hours, is positive in all respects. </p><p>Reacting to the release of the report, Eurofound Director <strong>Juan Menéndez-Valdés</strong> said, ‘Having a job is of most importance, but job quality also matters to people´s health and wellbeing. It is crucial to make work sustainable in longer working lives. It plays a key role in enhancing productivity and more importantly the day to day quality of life of hundreds of millions of European citizens; in this context the sixth European Working Conditions Survey is an essential resource for policymakers, both in Europe and further afield.’</p><p>Eurofound has been&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/surveys/european-working-conditions-surveys\" target=\"_blank\">monitoring working conditions in Europe for 25 years</a> and the sixth EWCS covers 35 European countries, which include the EU28, EU candidate countries, Norway and Switzerland. In total 43,850 workers, both employees and self-employed, were interviewed for the survey simultaneously. They were asked about their employment conditions, working hours, exposure to risks, work organisation, skills use and autonomy, work–life balance, health and well-being, and more.</p><p><strong>Find out what it is like to work in Europe:</strong> </p><li><a href=\"http://bit.ly/6EWCS2015\" target=\"_blank\">Click here for more information</a> on the sixth European Working Conditions Survey, including access to the&nbsp;comprehensive data visualisation tool</li><li>Click here to download the&nbsp;<a href=\"http://bit.ly/6EWCSReport\" target=\"_blank\">sixth European Working Conditions Survey – Overview report</a></li><li>Join the conversation on Twitter #6EWCS</li>\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:837:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a> </p><p>For more information about Eurofound and its work,\nand free access to all our data and findings, visit our <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu\">website</a> and follow us on these social media channels: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/eurofound\">Twitter</a>,&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/company/eurofound\" target=\"_blank\">LinkedIn</a>, and&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.facebook.com/eurofound.europa.eu\">Facebook</a>.&nbsp;</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";s:83:\"Find out what it is like to work in Europe: join the conversation on Twitter working conditions in Europe: Moving towards better work&nbsp;</em></strong><strong></strong><strong>launch event of<em>&nbsp;</em></strong><strong></strong><strong style=\"background-color: Affairs</a>. This latest edition of the survey covers 35 European countries (EU-28 and Norway, Switzerland, Albania, FYROM, Montenegro, Serbia, Turkey) and examines issues ranging from work-related physical and psychosocial risks, working time and work organisation&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;to developing skills at work and lifelong learning, work–life balance, work and gender and health and well-being.</p><p>The survey presents the diverse picture of Europe at work and underlines the complex reality with which Europe’s policymakers are confronted as they seek to build a fair and competitive Europe. It also maps changes in work over time and provides the first comprehensive image of job quality in Europe since the Great Recession. Its aim is to help policymakers improve working conditions and share evidence on people's everyday scenarios at work.</p><p>The one-day conference will bring together up to 200 policymakers, social partners, academics and representatives from national authorities and the European institutions.   1424347: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":30:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:7:\"1424347\";s:3:\"url\";s:126:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/europe-sees-slow-growth-in-face-of-economic-and-social-challenges-1424347\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-06-01 08:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-05-31 11:38:04\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-07-14 15:24:55\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:68:\"Download the 'Eurofound yearbook 2015: Living and Working in Europe'\";s:3:\"url\";s:21:\"http://bit.ly/LWE2015\";}}s:6:\"header\";s:65:\"Europe sees slow growth in face of economic and social challenges\";s:7:\"summary\";s:310:\"Eurofound has published its yearbook for 2015. The report shows that employment in Europe is on a slow growth trajectory after a long period of job loss and economic stagnation, but quality of life has slipped for many Europeans, and poverty is a threat for millions. Download the report: http://bit.ly/LWE2015\";s:4:\"body\";s:3423:\"<p><strong style=\"background-color: initial;\">(Dublin, Ireland): Employment in Europe is on a slow growth trajectory after a long period of job loss and economic stagnation but quality of life has slipped for many Europeans, and poverty is a threat for millions. This is according to the <em>Eurofound yearbook 2015: Living and working in Europe</em>, which presents an annual snapshot of economic and social developments, and how they affect the lives of Europeans across 28 Member States.</strong></p><p>Eurofound examined new sources of employment, new paths to employment and emerging new forms of employment that offer flexibility to enable workers to enter the labour market – themes of major interest as Europe seeks to regain the employment targets set in the Europe 2020 strategy for growth. But as employment rises, the Agency’s research shows that labour markets have become more polarised between high-skilled, high-paying jobs and low-skilled, low-paying jobs. A demand for flexible employment in the growing service sector, labour market deregulation and the working time choices of the growing numbers of female and older workers has given rise to more and atypical employment. </p><p>And while challenges remain in specific occupations - largely in the areas of pay and skills – Eurofound has found that working conditions have, in fact, remained stable across the board. Indeed, there have been some clear improvements in places - there has been a clear reduction in exposure to some workplace risks and fewer workers are working very long hours.  Furthermore, rising equality between women and men at work is a good news story, albeit still within a highly segregated labour market and with different experiences across dimensions and occupations. </p><p>At the same despite good development towards greater wage convergence in the years before the crisis, with marked growth particularly in some of the central and eastern European countries, wage inequalities have since begun to take hold again across Member States, with all the accompanying implications for worker mobility that will entail.</p><p>In this context, and as tensions rise in relation to migrant flows across the EU, Eurofound revealed that, in fact, overall, mobile workers from the central and east European EU10 take up benefits and use services to a lesser extent on the whole than the native population in the ‘richer’ host EU countries. And where they do access unemployment and other work-related benefits more than the host country workers, this is largely attributed to the fact that they are simply in more vulnerable job situations in any economic downturn.</p><p><strong>Download the <em>Eurofound yearbook 2015: Living and working in Europe</em>&nbsp;</strong><a href=\"http://bit.ly/LWE2015\" target=\"_blank\"><strong>here</strong></a><strong>.</strong></p><p><em style=\"background-color: initial;\">Eurofound celebrated the 40th anniversary of its founding in 2015. In 1975, the then European Community set up the Agency, charging it with the task of contributing to the planning and design of better living and working conditions in Europe. The social policy agenda and priorities may have shifted over those 40 years, but Eurofound’s mission throughout has been constant: to support policymakers to develop the best solutions for the social and work-related challenges faced by the European Union.&nbsp;</em></p>\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:837:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a> </p><p>For more information about Eurofound and its work,\nand free access to all our data and findings, visit our <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu\">website</a> and follow us on these social media channels: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/eurofound\">Twitter</a>,&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/company/eurofound\" target=\"_blank\">LinkedIn</a>, and&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.facebook.com/eurofound.europa.eu\">Facebook</a>.&nbsp;</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";s:114:\"The ‘Eurofound yearbook 2015: Living and Working in Europe’ shows the current challenges that Europe is facing\";s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/whhm4aafxj0zkpcbnxqr.png\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/whhm4aafxj0zkpcbnxqr.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/whhm4aafxj0zkpcbnxqr.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/whhm4aafxj0zkpcbnxqr.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/whhm4aafxj0zkpcbnxqr.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/whhm4aafxj0zkpcbnxqr.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:7:{i:0;s:8:\"business\";i:1;s:20:\"industrial relations\";i:2;s:13:\"labour market\";i:3;s:18:\"law and regulation\";i:4;s:15:\"social policies\";i:5;s:18:\"working conditions\";i:6;s:15:\"quality of   1386326: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":30:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:7:\"1386326\";s:3:\"url\";s:169:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/new-report-stresses-need-for-stronger-monitoring-of-labour-market-agencies-to-prevent-trafficking-of-workers-1386326\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-27 14:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-27 11:46:21\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-04-27 14:17:17\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:110:\"Regulation of labour market intermediaries and the role of social partners in preventing trafficking of labour\";s:3:\"url\";s:33:\"http://bit.ly/Prevent-Trafficking\";}}s:6:\"header\";s:108:\"New report stresses need for stronger monitoring of labour market agencies to prevent trafficking of workers\";s:7:\"summary\";N;s:4:\"body\";s:4636:\"<p><strong>(Dublin, Ireland): With growing numbers of workers moving freely across the European Union, the role of labour market intermediaries (LMIs) in matching workers with companies’ needs&nbsp;has become increasingly important in helping the single market to function effectively. However, some LMIs also play a part in the deceitful recruitment or transfer of workers who may subsequently be exposed to exploitation. New research, focusing on strategies to prevent such practices and limit the potential for trafficking, highlights the need for strengthened monitoring of LMIs to achieve better prevention, enforcement, sanctioning and prosecution.</strong></p><p><strong></strong></p><p><strong>Eurofound’s latest report </strong><strong><em>‘Regulation of labour market intermediaries and the role of social partners in preventing trafficking of labour’</em></strong><strong>, which is p</strong><strong>resented to members of the European Parliament in Brussels today,</strong><strong> also underlines the importance of social partner activities and cross-border cooperation in developing coherent and targeted interventions. </strong><strong></strong></p><p>Mobility and migration in the EU contribute to well-functioning labour markets, resulting in greater productivity, competitiveness and growth. The European Union has strong legislation in place, including to regulate labour market intermediaries, which enables businesses to engage in fair competition and protects workers from being exploited. Labour market intermediaries such as temporary work agencies help to facilitate the mobility of workers through matching workers with companies’ needs. According to the <a href=\"http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?query=BOOKMARK_DS-120959_QID_41A5C4B9_UID_-3F171EB0&amp;layout=TIME,C,X,0;GEO,L,Y,0;NACE_R2,L,Z,0;INDIC_SB,L,Z,1;SIZE_EMP,L,Z,2;INDICATORS,C,Z,3;&amp;zSelection=DS-120959INDICATORS,OBS_FLAG;DS-120959NACE_R2,H;DS-120959SIZE_EMP,TOTAL;DS-120959INDIC_SB,V11110;&amp;rankName1=SIZE-EMP_1_2_-1_2&amp;rankName2=INDICATORS_1_2_-1_2&amp;rankName3=INDIC-SB_1_2_-1_2&amp;rankName4=NACE-R2_1_2_-1_2&amp;rankName5=TIME_1_0_0_0&amp;rankName6=GEO_1_2_0_1&amp;sortC=ASC_-1_FIRST&amp;rStp=&amp;cStp=&amp;rDCh=&amp;cDCh=&amp;rDM=true&amp;cDM=true&amp;footnes=false&amp;empty=false&amp;wai=false&amp;time_mode=FIXED&amp;time_most_recent=false&amp;lang=EN&amp;cfo=%23%23%23%2C%23%23%23.%23%23%23\" target=\"_blank\">Structural Business Statistics</a> more than 33,000 temporary work agencies operate in Europe aiding job matching and mobility within and across borders.</p><p>While most LMIs abide by the rules, some use their role to recruit or transfer workers unlawfully. They deceive workers about the nature of the job, the employer, the location or other conditions related to the work, and these workers end up working under exploitative conditions. <a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/3888793/6648090/KS-TC-14-008-EN-1.pdf/b0315d39-e7bd-4da5-8285-854f37bb8801\" target=\"_blank\">Eurostat</a>’s latest figures show that 19% of all identified and presumed victims were trafficked for the purpose of labour exploitation. </p><p>In 2011 the EU adopted the <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2011:101:0001:0011:EN:PDF\" target=\"_blank\">Anti-Trafficking Directive</a>. The directive emphasises that trafficking is a serious crime and a gross violation of fundamental rights. <a href=\"https://ec.europa.eu/anti-trafficking/sites/antitrafficking/files/eu_strategy_towards_the_eradication_of_trafficking_in_human_beings_2012-2016_1.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">The EU Strategy towards the Eradication of Trafficking in Human Beings 2012–2016</a> complements the legal rules with targeted actions - and recruitment by LMIs is indeed one area of concern. </p><p>‘Although trafficking for labour exploitation has been criminalised at EU level, the recent numbers, according to <a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/3888793/6648090/KS-TC-14-008-EN-1.pdf/b0315d39-e7bd-4da5-8285-854f37bb8801\" target=\"_blank\">Eurostat</a>, of prosecuted traffickers are stagnant,’ says Andrea Fromm<strong>, </strong>Research Officer and co-author of the report.  ‘Our report urges stronger implementation of regulation and joint action by social partners to crack down on trafficking for labour exploitation.’</p><p><strong>Download the report <em>Regulation of labour market intermediaries and the role of social partners in preventing trafficking of labour: </em></strong><a href=\"http://bit.ly/Prevent-Trafficking\" target=\"_blank\">http://bit.ly/Prevent-Trafficking</a></p>\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";N;s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/nqeoefobl2zsuikldgo5.png\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/nqeoefobl2zsuikldgo5.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/nqeoefobl2zsuikldgo5.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/nqeoefobl2zsuikldgo5.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/nqeoefobl2zsuikldgo5.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/nqeoefobl2zsuikldgo5.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:3:{i:0;s:18:\"working   1301576: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":29:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:7:\"1301576\";s:3:\"url\";s:132:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/many-european-families-still-at-risk-of-poverty-despite-economic-growth-1301576\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2016-01-28 08:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2016-01-27 09:37:52\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2016-01-28 08:00:18\";s:6:\"header\";s:72:\"Many European families still at risk of poverty, despite economic growth\";s:7:\"summary\";s:274:\"Despite a return to economic growth, lone-parent families and large families with three or more dependent children face significant difficulties throughout Europe. In some countries more than eight out of ten lone-parent families are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. \";s:4:\"body\";s:4302:\"<p><strong style=\"background-color: initial;\">(Dublin, Ireland): Despite a return to economic growth, lone-parent families and large families with three or more dependent children face significant difficulties throughout Europe. In some countries more than eight out of ten lone-parent families are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. There are also large disparities between Member States, with families in some countries significantly more likely to have difficulty in making ends meet than others. This is according to the new report ‘<em>Families in the economic crisis: Changes in policy measures in the EU</em>’ which looks at the situation of families in Europe after the economic crisis, with an in-depth policy analysis of 10 Member States.</strong></p><p><strong></strong></p><p>The report highlights that there are 4.8 million more EU citizens living in poverty than in 2008, with families facing particular difficulties. Lone parents and large families are more likely to be at risk of poverty or social exclusion, or to have difficulties in making ends meet. However, there is a large divergence between Member States, due in part to different national level family policies as well as overall economic performance. The report found large disparities between the Nordic countries and newer EU Member States. For example, in 2012 a large Bulgarian family was more than 13 times more likely to have difficulty making ends meet than a large Finnish family. </p><p>The report highlights increasing evidence of a shift towards more means-tested support in relation to family benefits in Europe, and a reduction in universal support. This may create new groups of disadvantaged families who, before the crisis, had access to universal support measures. A combination of sufficient universal support for families, as well as means-tested support, is required in order to effectively assist struggling families. The report also highlights that changes to family policies since 2010 are largely the result of a range of conflicting issues; difficulty in equating the evolution of family needs with greater demands for cuts in public spending; and the need for equitable distribution of limited resources. This means family policies often lack a coherent and integrated policy framework, and are increasingly developed in reaction to specific emergencies and political inputs, rather than through coordinated and structural reforms. </p><p>The effectiveness of targeted measures aimed towards families is also often constrained by a narrow definition of what constitutes a family or a lone-parent family, and does not take into account changes in the make-up of families, such as ’blended’ families after divorce and re-marriage. The combination of a narrow definition of what constitutes a family and a shift towards more means-tested support has meant that families have lost out on vital support in some Member States. </p><p>Finally, the report emphasises that having a job is not the only answer for families at risk of poverty. Measures such as providing additional childcare support, or providing subsidised public transport can have a large positive impact and help to combat social exclusion. In particular, providing adequate, high-quality childcare that is not cost-prohibitive is a major factor in combating poverty and social exclusion and improving the quality of life for families throughout Europe. </p><ul> <li>Download the ‘Families in the economic crisis: Changes in policy measures in the EU’ report here: <a href=\"http://bit.ly/CrisisFamilies\">http://bit.ly/CrisisFamilies</a><strong></strong></li></ul><p><strong></strong></p><p><strong>For further information, contact: </strong><strong></strong></p><ul> <li>Måns Mårtensson, Media Manager, on email: <a href=\"mailto:mma@eurofound.europa.eu\">mma@eurofound.europa.eu</a>, telephone: +353-1-204 3124, or mobile: +353-876-593 507 <strong></strong></li><li>James Higgins, Promotions Officer, on email: <a href=\"mailto:jhi@eurofound.europa.eu\">jhi@eurofound.europa.eu</a>, and telephone: +353-1-204 3157<strong></strong></li><li>Daphne Nathalie Ahrendt, Research Manager, on email: <a href=\"mailto:dap@eurofound.europa.eu\">dap@eurofound.europa.eu</a> and telephone: +353-204 3168</li></ul><p><strong></strong></p>\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:1029:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a> </p><p>For more <a href=\"http://www.flickr.com/photos/eurofoundimages/\">Flickr</a>.&nbsp;</p>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/gcfgyfmuwyb3vwzoe2vu.png\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/gcfgyfmuwyb3vwzoe2vu.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/gcfgyfmuwyb3vwzoe2vu.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/gcfgyfmuwyb3vwzoe2vu.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/gcfgyfmuwyb3vwzoe2vu.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/gcfgyfmuwyb3vwzoe2vu.jpg\";s:4:\"tags\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:3:\"tag\";a:10:{i:0;s:7:\"familes\";i:1;s:7:\"poverty\";i:2;s:6:\"crisis\";i:3;s:6:\"social\";i:4;s:9:\"exclusion\";i:5;s:8:\"research\";i:6;s:10:\"employment\";i:7;s:9:\"childcare\";i:8;s:14:\"european
