  1012049: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":34:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:7:\"1012049\";s:3:\"url\";s:107:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/working-time-and-annual-holidays-divide-europe-1012049\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2014-06-24 13:30:50\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2014-06-24 13:23:00\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2014-06-24 13:30:56\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";a:2:{i:0;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:22:\"Download the report at\";s:3:\"url\";s:21:\"http://bit.ly/1nyLLMx\";}i:1;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:24:\"Download the report here\";s:3:\"url\";s:21:\"http://bit.ly/1nyLLMx\";}}}s:6:\"header\";s:46:\"Working time and annual holidays divide Europe\";s:7:\"summary\";s:401:\"The average collectively agreed weekly working time in the European Union stood at 38.1 hours in 2013, according to Eurofound’s latest working time update. The combined total of agreed annual leave and public holidays in the EU varied from 40 days in Germany and France to 29 days in Belgium - a difference of more than two working weeks. The Working Time Developments in Europe 2013 report is out. \";s:4:\"body\";s:4169:\"<p><b>(Dublin, Ireland): </b><b>The average collectively agreed weekly\nworking time in the European Union stood at 38.1 hours in 2013 (the same as in\n2012), according to Eurofound’s latest annual working time update. The working\nweek was on average 30 minutes shorter in the pre-2004 EU15 countries and over 90\nminutes longer in the new Member States. The report provides a snapshot of\nworking time developments in the European Union and Norway in 2013 as agreed\nbetween the social partners in collective agreements. The combined total of\nagreed annual leave and public holidays in the EU varied from 40 days in\nGermany and France to 29 days in Belgium – a difference of more than two\nworking weeks.</b></p>\n\n<p>Collective bargaining plays an important role\nin determining the duration of working time in most of the 28 Member States of\nthe European Union, though to a lesser or sometimes negligible extent in some\nof the Member States that joined the EU since 2004. This annual report provides\na general overview of collectively agreed working time and any major\ndevelopments taking place in 2013, and it includes data from all the EU Member\nStates and Norway.</p>\n\n<p>Czech Republic, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden and\nthe UK were the only countries registering changes between 2012 and 2013. The\nCzech Republic, Slovakia, and the UK registered an increase of 0.1 hours per\nweek, while Spain recorded a collectively agreed weekly working time which was\n0.3 hours higher in 2013 than in 2012. Sweden registered a decrease of 0.2\nhours compared with 2012.</p>\n\n<p>The report also looks at the average normal\nweekly working hours for full-time workers as set by collective bargaining in\nthree sectors representing the manufacturing industry, services and the public\nsector – chemicals, retail trade and civil service. These sectors do not differ\nsignificantly in terms of average agreed normal weekly working hours in the EU:\nthe civil service registered 38 hours; the chemicals sector, 38.1 hours; and\nretail, 38.3 hours.</p>\n\n<p>Actual weekly hours worked by full-time\nemployees were longer than the average normal collectively agreed working week\nin 18 of the 29 countries analysed in the report. In the EU28, the actual\nworking week was 39.5 hours in 2013, 0.1 hours less than in 2012; this was\nabout 1 hour and 24 minutes more than the average agreed working hours. In the\nEU15, the working week was 39.3 hours, about 1 hour and 42 minutes longer than\nthe agreed hours. In the 13 newer Member States, the working week was 40.1\nhours, about 24 minutes longer than the average agreed working hours.</p>\n\n<p>In 2013, actual weekly hours worked by male\nfull-time employees in their main jobs continued to exceed those of their\nfemale counterparts in all Member States, and Norway. Across the EU28, men\nworked on average two hours more than women. The gap is wider in the EU15 (2.3\nhours) than in the other 13 (1.4 hours). The sharpest differences were observed\nin Ireland and the UK (3.3 and 3.4 hours more, respectively), in Italy (2.8\nhours) and in Denmark, Finland, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Poland, and\nNorway (between two and 2.4 hours more). </p>\n\n<p>An important factor in the overall length of\nworking time is the paid annual leave to which workers are generally entitled,\nthe report points out. All 28 countries studied have a statutory minimum period\nof paid annual leave, and the average figure for the EU28, including paid leave\nand public holidays, stood at 35.3 days – 36.7 days in the EU15 and 31 days in\nthe NMS13. The report reveals big differences between countries, with employees\nin Germany and France enjoying up to 40 days of leave in total in 2013,\nfollowed by employees in Denmark (39 days) and Italy (37 days), while other\nnotably low-leave countries included Estonia, Hungary, Poland and Romania, with\n30 days, and Belgium with 29 days.</p>\n\n<p>Taking into account the\nagreed weekly hours, the days of leave and the public holidays, in 2013, the\naverage collectively agreed annual normal working time was approximately 1,712 hours\nin the EU28 (roughly the same as in 2012), 1,679 hours in the EU15, and 1,819\nhours in the NMS13.</p>\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:944:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a>&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p>For more information about Eurofound and its work,\nand free access to all our data and findings, visit our <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu\">website</a> and follow us on these social media channels: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/eurofound\">Twitter</a>, <a href=\"http://www.facebook.com/eurofound.europa.eu\">Facebook</a>, <a href=\"https://plus.google.com/+eurofound/\">Google+,</a> <a href=\"http://www.youtube.com/user/eurofound\">YouTube</a>, or <a href=\"http://www.flickr.com/photos/eurofoundimages/\">Flickr</a>.&nbsp;</p>\n\n<br>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/vdb4ra237eaoiw2xzqat.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/vdb4ra237eaoiw2xzqat.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/vdb4ra237eaoiw2xzqat.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/vdb4ra237eaoiw2xzqat.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/vdb4ra237eaoiw2xzqat.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/vdb4ra237eaoiw2xzqat.jpg\";s:12:\"attached_pdf\";s:69:\"http://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/b8ly1eoppmmkm5ekxdar.pdf\";s:21:\"attached_pdf_filename\";s:62:\"Press Keynote speakers include Nobel Price winner Sir Christopher Pissarides and Ioannis Vroutsis, Minister of Labour, Social Security and Welfare.\";s:4:\"body\";s:4490:\"<p>Although there are signs of recovery from the crisis, European labour\nmarkets and social conditions remain challenging. In the first phase of the\ncrisis, social dialogue showed resilience. However, as the crisis progressed\nthere has been evidence of weakening social dialogue and an exacerbation of trends\nsuch as the decrease in the number of agreements and a fall in union\nmembership.</p>\n\n<p>In cooperation with the Greek Presidency of the Council of the European\nUnion, Eurofound is organising a high-level conference Social Dialogue as a\ndriver in shaping and improving employment and working conditions in the EU in\nAthens on Monday 23 June 2014. This one-day conference will bring together\naround 100 participants, including representatives of government ministries,\nnational and European social partner organisations, the European Commission,\ninternational organisations, as well as experts and members of the academic\nworld. </p>\n<p><b>Date:</b>\nMonday 23 June 2014</p>\n\n<p><b>Time:</b>\n09.30 – 17.45</p>\n\n<p><b>Venue:</b>\nZappeion Exhibition Hall, Room 5,&nbsp;Ethnikos\nAthens 105 57</p>\n<p>The event will seek to draw lessons from the crisis and look to the\nfuture of social dialogue and its impact on employment and working conditions\nin the EU. The event will be an important forum for participants to hear about\nthe challenges partners in different Member States have faced and to look at\nthe way they have tackled various issues such as unemployment - particularly,\nyouth unemployment - the vulnerability of low-skilled workers and social\nexclusion.</p>\n\n<p>Taking place directly after the Employment and Social Affairs Council of\nMinisters meeting (EPSCO 19-20 June) from which Minister Vroutsis will bring\nfresh conclusions, the timing of the conference provides participants with the\nopportunity to examine key questions about the way EU-level social dialogue can\nsupport and strengthen national-level structures and the new roles for the\nnational and EU-level social partners. It will also be a chance to learn from\ncountries that have managed to combine effective social dialogue and\npartnership with strong economic performance.</p><p><b>Three interesting pointers:&nbsp;</b></p>\n<p><b>1. Keynote speakers: </b></p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Ioannis\nVroutsis, Minister of Labour, Social Security and Welfare, Greece </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Nobel Price\nwinner Sir Christopher Pissarides, Regius Professor of Economics, London School\nof Economics and Professor of European Studies, University of Cyprus.</p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Juan\nMenéndez-Valdés, Director, Eurofound</p>\n<p><b><br></b></p><p><b>2. On the path to\nrecovery – the role of social dialogue? </b></p>\n\n<p>This session will explore the different measures countries have pursued\nin order to&nbsp;restore their economies and the role of social dialogue. Presentations\nwill focus on the European overview and two different scenarios from Ireland\nand Portugal.</p>\n<p><b>Chair:</b> Stavroula Demetriades, Senior Programme Manager, Eurofound </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Christian\nWelz, Senior Programme Manager, Eurofound </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Manuel\nMarcelino Perata da Pena Costa, Vice-President, Confederation of </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Portuguese\nCommerce and Services </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Liam Kelly,\nHead of Industrial Relations and Social Dialogue Policy, Department of Jobs,\nEnterprise and Innovation, Ireland </p>\n<p><b>3. On the path to\nrecovery – social dialogue and the Greek experience</b></p>\n\n<p>On the path to recovery and addressing the challenges of a changing world\nof work&nbsp;and the demands for growth, development and prosperity, this session will\nexamine the&nbsp; role social dialogue can\nplay in Greece and how social dialogue is part of the solution.</p>\n<p><b>Chair: </b>Konstantinos Papadakis, Senior Liaison Office for Cyprus and\nGreece, </p>\n\n<p>International Labour Organisation (ILO) </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Dimitris\nDaskalopoulos, President, Hellenic Federation of Enterprises, (SEV) </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Giorgos\nKavathas, President, Hellenic Confederation of Professionals, Craftsmen, </p>\n\n<p>and\nMerchants (GSEVEE) </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Vassilis\nKorkidis, President, National Confederation of Hellenic Commerce (ESEE) </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Andreas\nAndreadis, President, Association of Greek Tourism Enterprises (SETE) </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Giannis\nPanagopoulos, President, General Confederation of Greek Workers (GSEE) </p>\n\n<p>·&nbsp; Odysseas\nDrivalas, President, Confederation of Greek Public Servants’ Unions </p>\n\n(ADEDY)<br>\n\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:944:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. However, because of lower inflation rates, employees in a number of European countries saw the purchasing power of their wages increase, reflecting a change from the post-crisis trend that had been observed since 2011. Eurofound’s annual update on pay is out. \";s:4:\"body\";s:2900:\"<p><b>(Dublin, Ireland):\n</b><b>Nominal collectively agreed\npay increases remained limited in the majority of EU Member States in 2013.\nHowever, because of lower inflation rates, employees in a number of European\ncountries saw the purchasing power of their wages increase, reflecting a change\nfrom the post-crisis trend that had been observed since 2011. Looking\nspecifically at the civil service, retail and chemicals sectors, pay freezes or\npay cuts were found in a majority of countries. Eurofound’s annual update on\npay reports on average increases of collectively agreed pay, outcomes of pay\nindexation mechanisms, pace-setting agreements and national or cross-sectoral\nagreements in all EU Member States, as well as minimum wage. </b></p>\n\n<p>Collective\nbargaining remains a major determinant of wage developments in Europe. There\nare, however, considerable variations between the EU countries and Norway in\nthe coverage of employees by collective wage bargaining. Generally, the\nthirteen Member States that joined the EU since 2004 have lower collective\nbargaining coverage than the older Member States. In the latter group, only\nPortugal and the United Kingdom have low bargaining coverage. Slovenia is the\nonly newer Member State that has high coverage.</p>\n\n<p>The\nhighest coverage of collective wage bargaining in Europe is found in Austria\nand Belgium, where virtually all employees are covered. Furthermore, in the\nmajority of countries, coverage appears to have decreased over the past decade.\nIn 10 countries, there has been a considerable decrease in coverage (more than\n10 percentage points). No Member State experienced a considerable increase in\ncoverage.</p>\n\n<p>The\nreport found that the change in real collectively agreed pay in 2013 was more\npositive than in 2012, for the majority of countries. In real terms,\ncollectively agreed pay increased the most in Slovakia (2.0%) and Sweden (1.6%)\nwhile it decreased the most in the United Kingdom (-1.6%).</p>\n\n<p>The\nreport also looks at the developments of statutory minimum wages in Europe. It\nfound that minimum wage levels increased by 10% or more in Lithuania, Estonia,\nRomania and Bulgaria, while it decreased in Greece. In real terms, the minimum\nwage decreased in six countries. </p>\n\n<p>Eurofound\nhas reported on developments in collectively agreed pay across Europe for\nalmost two decades. This year’s annual update on pay reports on average\nincreases of collectively agreed pay stemming from national databases, outcomes\nof pay indexation mechanisms, pace-setting agreements and national or\ncross-sectoral agreements. It explains these in relation to the national\nbargaining context and debate. The report also covers the outcomes of\nnegotiations in three sectors: the chemical industry, the retail sector and the\ncivil service. It also reports on developments in the area of statutory minimum\nwages.&nbsp;</p>\n\n<br>\n\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:944:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies.   982178: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":34:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:6:\"982178\";s:3:\"url\";s:180:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/positive-effects-of-steel-workers-direct-participation-in-managing-health-safety-and-psychosocial-risks-at-the-workplace-982178\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2014-04-08 12:30:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2014-04-08 11:19:12\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2014-04-08 14:01:40\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:24:\"Download the report here\";s:3:\"url\";s:65:\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/publications/htmlfiles/ef13102.htm\";}}s:6:\"header\";s:124:\"Positive effects of steel workers’ direct participation in managing health, safety and psychosocial risks at the workplace\";s:7:\"summary\";s:376:\"Encouraging people to talk about their problems at work, especially psychosocial problems, is a key element in prevention strategies. Eurofound releases a new report that looks at industrial relations practices regarding health and safety strategies in the European steel sector by analysing company practices in ArcelorMittal (FR), Rautaruukki (FIN) and Salzgitter AG (DE).  \";s:4:\"body\";s:2702:\"<p><b>(Dublin, Ireland): Direct involvement of all workers within an organisation with a view to achieving a culture of openness regarding psychosocial constraints at the workplace is one of the main challenges for the steel sector, according to Eurofound’s latest report on ‘Industrial relations practices related to psychosocial constraints at work in the steel sector’. Encouraging people to talk about their problems at work, especially psychosocial problems, is a key element in tackling the issue of the effectiveness of prevention strategies.</b></p>\n<p>The report looks at industrial relations practices regarding health and safety strategies in the European steel sector by analysing company practices in three case studies: ArcelorMittal in France, Rautaruukki in Finland and Salzgitter AG in Germany. The report compares the main findings on the role of social dialogue and company practices regarding prevention. It also highlights some specific company and sectoral features triggering psychosocial risks and their prevention.</p>\n<p>Although the three companies studied operate in different contexts (global, European, national, local), they are all confronted with psychosocial constraints at work. Issues such as stress, mental health and well-being are perceived as being not only detrimental to the health of workers, but as also having an economic impact on employers and civil society.</p>\n<p>The negative impacts of psychosocial problems arising at the workplace occur on economic performance (productivity) and human capital. For this reason, the three companies initiated a psychosocial risk assessment and subsequently compiled prevention measures. These took place in a wide variety of contexts, for example on the initiative of management, in the light of demographic change or following restructuring, but were part of the companies’ general policy and were supported by management.</p>\n<p>The report shows that the three companies have developed specific actions to deal with, reduce or prevent the incidence and negative impact of psychosocial constraints on both workers and the company. Real investments are therefore being made to implement awareness-raising programmes, train managers and prevent detrimental outcomes.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>The companies involve all workers, especially management, in addressing the issue. Triggering a collective behavioural change and involving all stakeholders within the organisation is therefore considered to constitute the key element and main on-going challenge. Existing formal and informal social dialogue channels represent an asset as they offer a place for an increased exchange of views between workers and employers.</p>\n\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:944:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a>&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p>For   976113: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":34:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:6:\"976113\";s:3:\"url\";s:140:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/increase-in-young-people-living-at-home-across-eu-since-onset-of-economic-crisis-976113\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2014-03-25 08:30:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2014-03-24 17:41:12\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2014-03-25 08:30:04\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";a:2:{i:0;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:22:\"Download the report at\";s:3:\"url\";s:21:\"http://bit.ly/1ileL9r\";}i:1;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:39:\"For more information about youth issues\";s:3:\"url\";s:20:\"http://bit.ly/NKyRie\";}}}s:6:\"header\";s:80:\"Increase in young people living at home across EU since onset of economic crisis\";s:7:\"summary\";s:379:\"The number of young people living at home with their parents across Europe has increased from 44% to 48% between 2007 and 2011, according to new research by Eurofound. The ‘Social situation of young people in Europe’, presented to policymakers in Dublin today, offer comparative insight across EU Member States of the social situation of youth in Europe and evolving trends. \";s:4:\"body\";s:3974:\"<p><b>(Dublin, Ireland):\nThe number of young people living at home with their parents across Europe has\nincreased from 44% to 48% between 2007 and 2011. This holds true especially for\nyoung men, according to new research by Eurofound into the social situation of\nyoung people in Europe. Nearly half of young people in the EU live in\nhouseholds experiencing some form of deprivation with 27% at moderate levels and\n22% experiencing serious deprivation. The ‘Social situation of young people in\nEurope’, presented to policymakers in Dublin today, puts emphasis on both\nsocial and employment issues affecting young people. The policy brief offers a\ncomparative insight across EU Member States of the social situation of youth in\nEurope and evolving trends. </b></p>\n\n<p>In most EU28 Member States, more young people were\nliving with their parents in 2011 than in 2007. This increase is significant\nfor both the younger age group (18–24 years), and the older group (25–29 years),\nand for both men and women. Young men are more likely to live with their\nparents than young women, and, as expected, those aged below 25 are more likely\nto live with their parents than those aged between 25 and 29. These\nproportions vary greatly by country. There were especially large increases in\nsome countries: the greatest increase recorded in Hungary (36%), followed by\nSlovenia (21%), Lithuania (17%) and Poland (15%). </p>\n\n<p>‘Tackling youth unemployment continues to be a policy priority for\nEuropean and national governments, but the need to directly address the risk of\nsocial exclusion and the need to look at the broader aspects of social\ninclusion are increasingly recognised in the public debate,’ says <b>Juan\nMenéndez-Valdés</b>, Director, Eurofound. ‘Remaining outside the\nlabour market has far-reaching consequences – not solely economic. These\ninclude a loss of confidence, an undermining of trust and expectations, and an\nincreasing risk of social exclusion and disengagement from society. With\nthis report, we have put the spotlight on the social situation of young people\nmost at risk, in an effort to further the debate and facilitate the tackling of\nthese challenges. ’</p>\n\n<p><b>Anna Ludwinek</b>,\nresearch manager, Eurofound explains: ‘This report shows that the economic\ncrisis has forced a growing number of young people to continue to live at home,\nwith serious implications for their independence, transition into adulthood and\neven on their perceived levels of social exclusion.’</p>\n\n<p>The report confirmed that both unemployed young people seeking work and\ninactive young people would like to work if they could freely choose their\nworking hours. This includes inactive young mothers and fathers looking after\ntheir children. Not surprisingly, the report found that unemployed and inactive\nyoung people are more likely than others to feel socially excluded, to feel\nlonely, to face a lack of social support, and to have lower levels of mental\nwell-being. It also found that young people are less likely to trust\ninstitutions in 2011 than they did in 2007, with the exception of the police,\nwhom they trust as much as before. Finally, it found that young people are more\nlikely than older people to perceive tensions between ethnic or religious\ngroups, as well as between groups of different sexual orientation.</p>\n\n<p>The new report is based on Eurofound’s European Quality of Life Survey\n(EQLS), a representative survey of those aged 18 and over in Europe, covering\nall EU countries and some acceding, candidate and potential candidate\ncountries. The survey aims to present a multidimensional picture of quality of\nlife in Europe, including questions on both the objective circumstances of\npeople’s lives (such as living conditions, income, deprivation) and their\nsubjective feelings and perceptions (such as life satisfaction and feeling of\nsocial exclusion). The most recent iteration of the survey took place in 2011.</p>\n\n<br>\n\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:944:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a>&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p>For more information about Eurofound and its work,\nand free access to all our data and findings, visit our <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu\">website</a> and follow us on these social media channels: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/eurofound\">Twitter</a>, <a href=\"http://www.facebook.com/eurofound.europa.eu\">Facebook</a>, <a href=\"https://plus.google.com/+eurofound/\">Google+,</a> <a href=\"http://www.youtube.com/user/eurofound\">YouTube</a>, or <a href=\"http://www.flickr.com/photos/eurofoundimages/\">Flickr</a>.&nbsp;</p>\n\n<br>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/kndizvn5a7fbeyfvjuvx.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/kndizvn5a7fbeyfvjuvx.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/kndizvn5a7fbeyfvjuvx.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/kndizvn5a7fbeyfvjuvx.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/kndizvn5a7fbeyfvjuvx.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/kndizvn5a7fbeyfvjuvx.jpg\";s:12:\"attached_pdf\";s:69:\"http://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/y3mmlugzixhekizbn405.pdf\";s:21:\"attached_pdf_filename\";s:71:\"Press   969447: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":34:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:6:\"969447\";s:3:\"url\";s:131:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/wage-setting-mechanisms-and-minimum-wages-under-the-spotlight-in-europe-969447\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2014-03-06 15:00:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2014-03-06 13:51:37\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2014-03-06 15:00:05\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:22:\"Download the report at\";s:3:\"url\";s:21:\"http://bit.ly/1fDVDEG\";}}s:6:\"header\";s:71:\"Wage setting mechanisms and minimum wages under the spotlight in Europe\";s:7:\"summary\";s:354:\"The 'Pay in Europe in the 21st century' report provides comparative time series on wage-bargaining outcomes across the EU Member States and Norway. It also investigates the different systems and levels of minimum wages in Europe at present, evaluating the implications of a hypothetical scenario of a minimum wage set at 60% of the median national wage. \";s:4:\"body\";s:5769:\"<p><b>(Dublin, Ireland): While wage-bargaining regimes have remained stable over time in many countries, the post-crisis period after 2009 saw an acceleration of collective bargaining being delegated to more decentralised bargaining structures and reduced bargaining coverage. Comparing collectively agreed pay with actual compensation, the Central and Eastern European countries are catching up with European averages. The <i>Pay in Europe in the 21st century</i> report provides comparative time series on wage-bargaining outcomes across the EU Member States and Norway. It also investigates the different systems and levels of minimum wages in Europe at present, evaluating the implications of a hypothetical scenario of a minimum wage set at 60% of the median national wage and discussing the possibilities and difficulties of coordination in this matter. The report will be presented to government representatives of EU Member States on Friday 7 March 2014.&nbsp;</b></p>\n<p>The issue of wages has attracted particular attention at European level since the onset of the economic crisis. Changes in economic governance, notably within the European semester, have brought discussions on wage-setting mechanisms to the fore. While overall, wage-bargaining regimes have remained rather stable over time in many countries, the most substantial changes were seen in programme countries and in other Member States facing more difficult economic situations in the post-crisis period after 2009. The report found, however, that the acceleration of decentralisation, with more bargaining being delegated to the company level, has not affected the predominant level of central or sectoral bargaining in most Member States – at least, not for the time being.</p>\n<p>When looking at actual levels of compensation during the period between 1998 and 2012, the report found that actual compensation per employee rose on an annual average between 0.9% in Italy and 22% in Romania, with the European median at 3.5% per year. Higher growth rates of actual compensation per employee, mainly in the new Member States, reflect how the countries in Central and Eastern Europe are catching up with European averages, ranging from 4.5% in Croatia to 10% in Latvia. The lowest increases took place in Italy, Germany, Austria, Cyprus and France, all between 1% and 3%.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>In terms of wage share within the economies, the overall trend was that of a declining one in most Member States (except in the Czech Republic, Finland and the United Kingdom, where the wage share is growing). However, in the majority of countries with decentralised bargaining systems and low coordination, the wage share declined during the crisis. In contrast, in the majority of countries with other systems, real unit labour costs increased.</p>\n<p>The report found that increases in collectively agreed pay were lowest in the country group with sector-level and highly coordinated bargaining, while they were highest in countries with intermediate-level bargaining and a low degree of coordination. At the sectoral level, disparities in terms of collectively agreed pay have increased over time between the public sector (local governments and civil service) and the private sectors covered in the study (metal, chemicals, retail and banking), mainly because in the public sector of many countries across Europe, pay was frozen or only moderately increased.</p>\n<p>Collectively agreed pay remains an important driver of actual pay in many countries, and it is the component of pay that can be most influenced by the actors involved. Collectively agreed pay refers to basic wages only, while actual wage bills include overtime payments, bonuses, stock options or other forms of variable pay.</p>\n<p>Minimum wages can be considered as a cornerstone of the ‘European Social Model’. They exist in all EU Member States, even if they are set up and established in very different ways and do not cover all those who are employed in all Member States. In general, minimum wages are not explicitly aimed at reducing wage inequality and poverty, but at establishing a minimum rate under which any employment relationship is considered to be unacceptable - in other words, the establishment of morally based labour standards.</p>\n<p>In the majority of EU Member States, minimum wages are set by government regulation. Germany together with Austria, Denmark, Finland, Italy and Sweden are the exceptions, where minimum wages are set by collective bargaining agreements and do not cover all workers. Monthly statutory minimum wages or average collective agreed minimum wages in EU Member States are estimated at between €122,7 (Romania) to €1,788 (Luxembourg).&nbsp;</p>\n<p>The report evaluates the implications of a hypothetical scenario of a minimum wage set at 60% of the median national wage and discusses the possibilities and difficulties of coordination in this matter.</p>\n<p>The quantitative impact of such a policy would vary considerably across countries: it would be largest in the Baltic countries, Germany, Ireland, Poland, Romania and the UK, and smallest in Belgium, France the Nordic countries, Portugal and Slovakia. Germany stands out from the rest, where almost one in four German workers would see their wages increase with the establishment of a minimum wage threshold of of 60% of the median.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>The report also found that a minimum wage set at 60% of the median would disproportionately affect women (21.5% of female workers versus 11% of male) and young workers (35% of those in 20-24 years age group, 16% of those in 25-29 age group, versus 12% of those in 30-55 years age groups). The biggest impact would be in the personal services sectors and in small companies.</p>\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:944:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a>&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p>For more information about Eurofound and its work,\nand free access to all our data and findings, visit our <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu\">website</a> and follow us on these social media channels: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/eurofound\">Twitter</a>, <a href=\"http://www.facebook.com/eurofound.europa.eu\">Facebook</a>, <a href=\"https://plus.google.com/+eurofound/\">Google+,</a> <a href=\"http://www.youtube.com/user/eurofound\">YouTube</a>, or <a href=\"http://www.flickr.com/photos/eurofoundimages/\">Flickr</a>.&nbsp;</p>\n\n<br>\";s:13:\"image_caption\";N;s:5:\"image\";s:70:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/c9uzzustocra6ma2k89y.jpg\";s:11:\"image_small\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_480/c9uzzustocra6ma2k89y.jpg\";s:12:\"image_medium\";s:99:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_next_gen_article_large_767/c9uzzustocra6ma2k89y.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_large\";s:83:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_v2/c9uzzustocra6ma2k89y.jpg\";s:22:\"image_thumbnail_medium\";s:90:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_article_medium_v2/c9uzzustocra6ma2k89y.jpg\";s:21:\"image_thumbnail_small\";s:89:\"https://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/t_small_square_fit/c9uzzustocra6ma2k89y.jpg\";s:12:\"attached_pdf\";s:69:\"http://resources.mynewsdesk.com/image/upload/kb63tzaasejz0satqcba.pdf\";s:21:\"attached_pdf_filename\";s:64:\"Press   960000: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":34:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:6:\"960000\";s:3:\"url\";s:150:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/high-levels-of-restructuring-activity-in-the-midst-of-improved-economic-outlook-for-europe-960000\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2014-02-11 13:15:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2014-02-11 12:49:37\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2014-02-11 13:15:01\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";a:2:{i:0;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:29:\"Download the ERM quarterly at\";s:3:\"url\";s:21:\"http://bit.ly/1fc0SGc\";}i:1;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:43:\"Access the restructuring events database at\";s:3:\"url\";s:21:\"http://bit.ly/1eQ8P7u\";}}}s:6:\"header\";s:90:\"High levels of restructuring activity in the midst of improved economic outlook for Europe\";s:7:\"summary\";s:342:\"Recent months have seen an improvement in economic outlook but large-scale restructuring activity in the EU continues to result in greater announced job losses than job gains. The latest European Restructuring Monitor ERM quarterly is out, highlighting job loss and job creation activities and restructuring trends across the European Union. \";s:4:\"body\";s:2494:\"<p><b>(Dublin, Ireland): The European Restructuring Monitor (ERM) recorded a total of 345 cases of restructuring between 1 October and 31 December 2013. Of these, 230 were cases of announced restructuring involving job loss, 104 were cases involving announced job creation and 11 were cases involving both job loss and job creation. The biggest single case of job loss was that of Poctza Polska (the Polish national mail operator) which announced 4,000 voluntary redundancies in 2014, following similar levels of personnel reduction in 2012 and 2013. The troubled Italian bank, Monte dei Paschi di Siena, announced the closure of 150 branches in Italy with 3,300 job losses by the end of 2014.&nbsp;</b></p>\n<p>In total, large-scale restructuring cases in the quarter comprised a total of 96,245 announced job losses and 37,529 announced job gains. Internal restructuring accounted for over 70% of the announced job losses, while the incidence of job loss due to bankruptcy (11%) and closures (9%) decreased compared to the previous quarter.</p>\n<p>The manufacturing sector experienced the most restructuring activity involving job losses, accounting for over 30% of total job losses, while transport and storage accounted for the majority of job gains (over 30% of total job gains).</p>\n<p>In terms of geographical distribution, the countries which recorded the greatest number of announced job losses were the United Kingdom (13,838 jobs) and Germany (13,506 jobs), followed by France (11,705 jobs), Spain (10,142 jobs), Greece (6,537 jobs) and Italy (6,457 jobs). The Czech Republic (9,529 jobs) recorded the highest number of new jobs, followed by France (6,020 jobs), Poland (4,558 jobs), the United Kingdom (3,528 jobs) and Germany (3,370 jobs).</p>\n<p>The new edition of the <i>ERM quarterly</i> provides a sector focus on US online retailer Amazon’s expansion in central and Eastern Europe, following the announcement of over 6,000 new jobs in four new Amazon distribution centres in Poland and the Czech Republic. The report also includes brief news items on the closure of Ràdio Televisió Valenciana (RTVV), the regional Spanish broadcaster, in November 2013, and Liepajas Metalurgs (LM), the largest steel producer in the Baltics, that filed for bankruptcy with the loss of 1,500 jobs.&nbsp; The final feature outlines some of the public initiatives that have been assisting Greek employers during the period of readjustment since the economic and financial crisis post 2008</p>\n\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:1489:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a>&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p>The European Restructuring Monitor (ERM) is a unique EU-wide dataset on larger-scale restructuring events, It monitors the announced employment effects of restructuring in the EU28 and Norway. The ERM is updated on a daily basis and can serve to identify emerging restructuring trends in terms of country, sector or type of restructuring (eg. offshoring). The monitor relies on news reports in selected media titles in each member state. To date, it includes details of over 16,000 individual restructuring cases going back to 2002.&nbsp;</p><p>For more information about Eurofound and its work,\nand free access to all our data and findings, visit our <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu\">website</a> and follow us on these social media channels: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/eurofound\">Twitter</a>, <a   937251: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":31:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:6:\"937251\";s:3:\"url\";s:138:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/the-economic-crisis-has-significantly-reduced-the-rate-of-offshoring-in-europe-937251\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2013-12-04 18:30:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2013-12-04 17:32:08\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2013-12-04 18:30:01\";s:6:\"header\";s:78:\"The economic crisis has significantly reduced the rate of offshoring in Europe\";s:7:\"summary\";s:402:\"The offshoring share of restructuring job loss in Europe peaked before the 2008–2009 crisis and has remained lower ever since, according to the 2013 annual report of the European Restructuring Monitor (ERM) - Monitoring and managing restructuring in the 21st century. The report also presents a retrospective of over a decade of monitoring the impact of large-scale restructuring activity in Europe. \";s:4:\"body\";s:3539:\"<p><b>(Dublin, Ireland): The economic crisis has significantly reduced the rate of offshoring in Europe, according to the 2013 annual report of the European Restructuring Monitor (ERM) - <i>Monitoring and managing restructuring in the 21st century</i>. The report, which is launched at a high-level EU-Japan tripartite meeting on employment and social issues in Tokyo today, found that the offshoring share of restructuring job loss in Europe peaked before the 2008–2009 crisis and has remained lower ever since. The report also presents a retrospective of over a decade of monitoring the impact of large-scale restructuring activity in Europe.</b>&nbsp;</p>\n<p>In the last decades, significant offshoring has accompanied dramatic changes in the international division of labour. However, offshoring accounts for a low share of large-scale restructuring job loss, less than 12% in every quarter since the ERM restructuring events database started in 2002. The main destination for offshored jobs are the central and eastern European [CEE] countries. China, India and other Asian countries account together for around a third of offshored jobs. Half of offshored jobs remain in Europe.</p>\n<p>Offshoring job loss tended to be higher in smaller, western European member states. At least one in every six jobs (17%) lost through restructuring in Denmark, Ireland and Portugal was offshored, much higher than the EU average of 6%. Manufacturing accounts for the majority of offshored jobs in all Member States except the UK, where services offshoring predominates.</p>\n<p>By firm nationality, foreign-owned firms accounted for a higher share of offshoring job loss post-2008 (46%) compared to 2003–2008 (66%). The share of domestically owned firms declined. More than a quarter (28%) of offshoring job losses in non-domestic, EU-owned firms were the consequence of cases of either full reshoring or partial reshoring to the country of ownership. German and Italian firms were those most likely to reshore.</p>\n<p>The 2013 annual report from the European Restructuring Monitor also presents a retrospective of over a decade of measuring the impact of large-scale restructuring activity in Europe. In particular, the report focuses on comparing activity in the pre-crisis period (2003–2008) with the post-crisis period (2008–2013) in order to identify changes in the prevalence of different restructuring practices, and to show which sectors have been disproportionately affected, in employment terms, by the global recession.</p>\n<p>The crisis and post-crisis periods have seen a notable increase in the share of restructuring job loss attributable to bankruptcy or closure, and a decrease in the share attributable to offshoring or relocation as well as mergers and acquisitions. The destruction of employment has been felt most acutely in manufacturing and construction. Together, these two broad sectors account for well over 100% of the net employment losses experienced since 2008.</p>\n<p>Austerity policies have seen a rise in the public sector share of restructuring job loss from 2011 onwards. Many of the largest recent ERM restructuring cases have been in public administration. This is in contrast to the period of global crisis (2008-9) when employment held up well in predominantly publicly funded sectors. More recently private services employment growth has been much more resilient.&nbsp;</p><p><a href=\"http://bit.ly/ermar13\" target=\"_blank\"><b>More information is available at http://bit.ly/ermar13</b></a><b></b></p>\n\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:944:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a>&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p>For   933037: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":32:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:6:\"933037\";s:3:\"url\";s:146:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/despite-recession-eu-companies-have-difficulties-finding-workers-with-the-right-skills-933037\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2013-11-26 06:30:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2013-11-25 22:35:24\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2013-11-26 06:30:00\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";a:2:{i:0;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:32:\"More information is available at\";s:3:\"url\";s:22:\"http://bit.ly/3ecs2013\";}i:1;O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:19:\"Survey mapping tool\";s:3:\"url\";s:21:\"http://bit.ly/18BOznH\";}}}s:6:\"header\";s:88:\"Despite recession, EU companies have difficulties finding workers with the right skills \";s:7:\"summary\";s:392:\"In the midst of Europe’s greatest recession, 40% of all EU companies have difficulties finding workers with the right skills. For innovative companies, this is even more challenging. This emerges from Eurofound’s third European Company Survey (ECS), launched in Brussels on 26 November 2013. The European Company Survey (ECS) maps what is happening in companies across the European Union.\";s:4:\"body\";s:3598:\"<p><b>(Dublin, Ireland): In the midst of Europe’s greatest recession, 40% of all EU companies have difficulties finding workers with the right skills. For innovative companies, this is even more challenging. This emerges from Eurofound’s third European Company Survey (ECS), launched in Brussels today, which provides a snapshot of human resource management practices, employee participation and social dialogue at the workplace, and performance and innovation. In some countries, both social partnership is strong and a high level of social dialogue is taking place, and there is also extensive innovation in work organisation. In-depth analysis will explore whether and how these phenomena are linked in differing national settings, sectors of activity and company types.</b></p>\n<p>Workplace innovation is increasingly recognised as a driver for reaching the Europe 2020 targets of smart, inclusive and sustainable growth, contributing to creating jobs, developing human capital and boosting productivity. The European Company Survey (ECS) maps what is happening in companies across the European Union.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Over a third of companies and establishments in Europe have introduced innovation measures and report that their financial situation has improved. Changes like product and process innovation or changes in technology at company level are helping firms to be more resilient and exit the recession.</p>\n<p>How companies organise their work is important in facilitating innovation, improving performance and ensuring good job quality. The third ECS found that more than two-thirds (68%) of staff monitor external ideas and technological developments for new products, services and processes and almost as many (62%) document good practice or lessons learned so that these may be shared with colleagues. Almost two-thirds of companies and establishments (63%) use some kind of variable pay, and this is most commonly linked to individual performance.</p>\n<p>In companies and establishments with a formal employee representation, nine out of ten employee representatives report that they are informed by management about the financial and employment situation.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>The survey also found that social partnership is strong and a high level of social dialogue is taking place in Europe’s companies and establishments. It found that almost nine out of ten establishments and companies (88%) have structures in place for employee representation, in which workers are informed about the most important recent decision affecting working conditions. In seven out of ten workplaces (69%), employees are asked to give their views before any decision is taken, and in six out of ten (60%) workplaces employees are involved in joint decision-taking with management over the decision.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>The third ECS provides new data on how organisations are organised – in particular, how employees and their representatives are involved in improving work organisation and work processes. In doing so it aims to contribute to a better understanding of how to facilitate economic growth for Member States and better outcomes for employees. It maps practices in establishments with 10 or more employees across the EU28 with regard to work organisation, human resource (HR) practices, employee participation and social dialogue, and how these practices support ‘smart growth’. The fieldwork for the third ECS was carried out in the spring of 2013, involving senior decision-makers responsible for staff and employee representatives in 30,000 companies in 32 countries.&nbsp;</p><br>\n\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:944:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a>&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p>For more information about Eurofound and its work,\nand free access to all our data and findings, visit our <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu\">website</a> and follow us on these social media channels: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/eurofound\">Twitter</a>, <a href=\"http://www.facebook.com/eurofound.europa.eu\">Facebook</a>, <a href=\"https://plus.google.com/+eurofound/\">Google+,</a> <a href=\"http://www.youtube.com/user/eurofound\">YouTube</a>, or <a   926818: !php/object "O:8:\"stdClass\":29:{s:10:\"newsdeskML\";s:3:\"2.1\";s:13:\"type_of_media\";s:12:\"pressrelease\";s:8:\"language\";s:2:\"en\";s:9:\"source_id\";s:5:\"52528\";s:11:\"source_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:14:\"pressroom_name\";s:9:\"Eurofound\";s:9:\"pressroom\";s:2:\"uk\";s:12:\"pressroom_id\";s:5:\"58119\";s:19:\"organization_number\";N;s:2:\"id\";s:6:\"926818\";s:3:\"url\";s:115:\"http://www.mynewsdesk.com/uk/eurofound/pressreleases/inequalities-in-well-being-rise-in-europe-during-crisis-926818\";s:12:\"published_at\";s:19:\"2013-11-18 22:26:00\";s:10:\"created_at\";s:19:\"2013-11-08 16:52:06\";s:10:\"updated_at\";s:19:\"2013-11-25 22:37:21\";s:5:\"links\";O:8:\"stdClass\":1:{s:4:\"link\";O:8:\"stdClass\":2:{s:4:\"text\";s:21:\"More information here\";s:3:\"url\";s:22:\"http://bit.ly/eqls2013\";}}s:6:\"header\";s:55:\"Inequalities in well-being rise in Europe during crisis\";s:7:\"summary\";s:385:\"While life satisfaction increased marginally across the European Union between 2007 and 2011, happiness and optimism levels have fallen and perceived social exclusion has increased, indicating a decline in overall well-being in many European countries. Eurofound’s new report is the first in a series of reports which covers trends in quality of life in Europe over the past decade. \";s:4:\"body\";s:4971:\"<p><b>(Dublin, Ireland):\n</b><b>While\nlife satisfaction increased marginally across the European Union between 2007\nand 2011, happiness and optimism levels have fallen and perceived social\nexclusion has increased, indicating a decline in overall well-being in many European\ncountries during the crisis. Eurofound’s new report assesses the impact of the\ncrisis on the subjective well-being of Europeans, drawing policy-relevant\nfindings from its third European Quality of Life Survey (EQLS). It is the first\nin a series of reports which covers social inequalities, quality of society and\npublic services, and trends in quality of life in Europe over the past decade.</b> </p>\n\n<p>The results from the latest EQLS, fielded in\nall 28 EU Member States as well as six further European countries, shows how\nthe crisis is affecting some groups more than others. &nbsp;The report identifies Europeans limited by\nillness or disability, those who are separated or divorced, and individuals in\nthe middle-age bracket of 35–49 years as more likely to have low well-being.\nThe lowest levels of subjective well-being are reported by people who are\nunemployed. The report goes on to identify particular dimensions of well-being where\ncountries do poorly but also where they do well: for example, high levels of\nstress are found in France, high levels of loneliness in Italy and low levels\nof vitality in the UK; conversely, a high level of education satisfaction is noted\nin Romania and the Netherlands reports low levels of time pressure. </p>\n\n<p>Many countries with\nhigher levels of life satisfaction in 2007 reported lower satisfaction in 2011.\nIn countries where there have been increases in well-being, they tend to have\nbeen enjoyed by those in the highest-income quartiles. Conversely, the largest\nfalls were experienced by those in the bottom-income quartile, indicating that\nthe gap in well-being between the wealthiest and the poorest members of the\npopulation has grown during the crisis. </p>\n\n<p>At the national level, the analysis sounds\nwarning bells for Finland, the Netherlands and Sweden – all witnessing\ndeclining levels of subjective well-being despite the relatively moderate\nimpact of the economic crisis in these countries. Nevertheless, the countries\nin the cluster of least unequal countries, i.e. the Nordic countries and the\nNetherlands – continue to enjoy the highest levels of well-being on most\nmeasures. The Netherlands also has the lowest level of well-being inequality in\nEurope. It is important to note that these countries do not perform well just\nbecause they are wealthy. Denmark and Sweden have lower GDPs per capita than\nIreland, and Finland has a lower GDP per capita than Germany. Data on\nwell-being allow policymakers to identify the groups and countries that are\nbearing the brunt of the economic crisis, as well as those that are doing\nbetter than expected, and provides a new layer of evidence to aid policy. </p>\n\n<p>Analysing well-being at a time of crisis is\nmore relevant than ever before as it shows how different aspects of quality of\nlife are affected, thereby informing debate on policy trade-offs. The report\nexplores new empirical evidence on possible protective factors, showing for\ninstance that not being in debt is an important factor for the well-being of\npeople on low income. As Rob Anderson, team leader of Eurofound’s European\nquality of life survey, explains “these analyses help policy-makers identify\nthe types of measures that could protect people who are already in vulnerable\nsituations against loss of well-being”.</p>\n\n<p>The report presents an innovative way of\nlooking at inequalities in well-being; to measure the distribution of\nwell-being within a country, differences in life satisfaction between the 20%\nwith the highest life satisfaction and the 20% with the lowest life\nsatisfaction in each country were computed. In addition, in each country it\npresents the average distance in life satisfaction between two individuals\nchosen at random. These analyses identify Bulgaria, Hungary, Slovakia, Cyprus,\nRomania, the UK and Austria as having particularly large differences in\nwell-being inequality.</p>\n\n<p>The evidence suggests clear benefits from reducing\nincome inequalities within a country. Rising inequality may be linked to\ndeclining well-being in the countries with higher\nlevels of life satisfaction in 2007, despite\nrising average incomes. Improving the situation of the least well-off is most\nlikely to result in the largest gains in well-being.</p>\n\n<p>This report is one of a series of new reports\nfrom Eurofound which examine the results from the third EQLS and changes in\nrecent years. These include the overview report <i>Quality of life in Europe:\nImpacts of the crisis </i>(Eurofound, 2012) and the new reports on subjective\nwell-being, social inequalities, quality of society and public services, and trends\nin quality of life in Europe over the past decade 2003–2012.</p>\n\";s:11:\"boilerplate\";s:944:\"<p>The European Foundation for the Improvement of\nLiving and Working conditions (Eurofound)&nbsp;is a tripartite European Union\nAgency, whose role is to provide knowledge in the area of social and\nwork-related policies. Eurofound was established in 1975 by <a href=\"http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:01975R1365-20050804:EN:NOT\">Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1365/75. </a>&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p>For more information about Eurofound and its work,\nand free access to all our data and findings, visit our <a href=\"http://www.eurofound.europa.eu\">website</a> and follow us on these social media channels: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/eurofound\">Twitter</a>, <a href=\"http://www.facebook.com/eurofound.europa.eu\">Facebook</a>, <a href=\"https://plus.google.com/+eurofound/\">Google+,</a> <a href=\"http://www.youtube.com/user/eurofound\">YouTube</a>, or <a
